Hopefully you will enjoy watching this anime unlike me who hated it. If I were you i probably won't waste my time on this anime.

Alright, I first want to start of by saying this is my first review I have ever done, so please bare with me, I'll be using the general layout to help me with the foundations of my review.
If you've ever been into a situation where you don't want to school based on how you perceive yourself? Well, I can say for myself that I very much related to the concept of this anime, lacking the hot girls as friends.
I would say for people to read a review with a reasonable rating, I've been seeing 3/10's and even lower, it's only been three episodes, can onereally slap on something so demeaning when it first starts out? 


Story : 8

The story takes place in 2046, a very interesting date to start off an Anime, as we usually have things from earlier dates, or from the next century, but I won't drag on about that. The main character is Haruyuki Arita, a young boy suffering from bullying and harassment from other students, he finds relief in the net, which allows him to release his anger on one of his favourite video games. One faithful day, one of the most popular students in class notices his ideals and goal sets to always want to be the best in  any video game he plays. After awhile she gives him the opportunity to take part in a project called "Brain Burst", basically a fighting game.


I really do love these ideas for animes, as they're interesting and allow for a decently paced, not too fast, not too slow. The main character is chubby? we never see this actually executed in a serious anime, as most people always want their main characters to be perfect, completely biased without a doubt. 


I for one relate to the story, maybe that's why I feel it's right to give such a work a good score like this? maybe because in the three episodes(10 chapters in manga, I believe) that this will for sure have potential to impact how things are done.



Art : 9

The art style is quite amazing, for a lack of a better word. Everything is nice and crisp, yet smooth. Landscapes are very nicely done and scenery. Character design is pretty much at the standards and surpassing the standards in some aspects. Many people I found comment on the main characters design, but think about it like this, would he really look better with different eyes given his body structure? maybe some comment on this as chibi'esque, but I don't believe it is.



Sound : 9

The opening and endings for this anime are very nice, and really blend well with the anime itself as a whole, I enjoy listening to the soundtracks occasionally. The opening, sang by the amazing May'n, was amazingly done, the soundtracks played during the anime episodes themselves to give off the mood of the situations really were done nicely, I had no problems what so ever sound wise.



Character : 8

Before I begin on this aspect, I would like to say, this is very early, so we really can't comment on character development and such via different scenarios/situations. The main character seems to be a bit of a wimp, due to how he's treated and such, so that gives off his overall personality, that he really has problems expanding out to other people, maybe he's embarrassed about his weight? People have to think outside of the box before they comment on this aspect.


Kuroyukihime, in my opinion is a bit of a generic Moe, persuades Haruyuki to help her in her little ulterior motive to figure out the secrets and such. Though I consider her one of my favourites, mainly because she can fall in love with a guy like Haruyuki, now that takes a lot of work, and we barely see it, yeah I know, UNREALISTIC ATTRACTIONS, but come on guys, think outside the box, maybe she likes him for how he acts in regards to wanting to be the best?



Enjoyment : 9

I very much enjoyed this anime, how it is so far, after finishing episode 3, I quickly headed over to MF to read the manga of it to where it is currently. I'm already hooked.


Overall : 8.5


A must watch, take my word on it, please don't follow on with the complete biased reviews, I enjoyed this, because I enjoyed it.

Accel World is a bit of a mixed bag for me to deliver my thoughts on. Taking place in a future where augmented reality is the norm with the younger generation, a bullied outcast named Haruyuki meets up with popular girl Kuroyukihime who gives him a game called Brain Burst that allows him and others with the game to have the ability to accelerate their capabilities in the real world and face off against other users of the game to compete for Burst Points that allow one use of their abilities.
While the series does have some interesting elements to it via its battle system andthe means that characters have to "accelerate" in the real world, the series suffers in the fact that it doesn't really feel like anything too serious outside of the game is at stake for anyone and the motivations that others have for being in the game feel kind of petty, reducing any major tension that could engage me to care for anything besides the show's Brain Burst elements. Sure, there's mention and showing of characters dealing with bullying, neglect or family abuse that the series says is what manifests a user's ability to use Brain Burst. But the motivations for many characters are no different from if you wanted to play an MMORPG with getting stronger, having allies to form alliances, gaining new skills/items or purposely breaking the rules for your personal gain; which I've already experienced from the Dot Hack franchise which at least had some major stakes to it during its first generation run with Sign thanks to the nasty effects any human player getting struck with Data Drain would experience in the real world. Here in Accel World though, the worst thing that would happen is all your Burst Points are lost and you lose accessibility to Brain Burst as no one is at risk of dying in real life (except for one instance at the start of the series unrelated to the game).


The characters are a bit of a mixed bunch. The major ones have character archetypes that they fulfill, yet get enough fleshing out to have you care for them in many instances, though Haruyuki's occasional angst fits would have me tempted to want to whack him. The majority of the secondary ones, on the other hand, don't get so much and are mostly reduced to archetypes. The anime does introduce a faction of villains and a plot element that affects Haruyuki's experience in Brain Burst for the second half of the series. But with this being based on an ongoing light novel series, these plot developments are left unresolved.


Visually, Accel World's regular character designs are on the plain side following the standard anime style and Haruyuki's design is of particular note as he is drawn differently from other characters and seems more like he'd be suited for a slapstick anime comedy with his appearance, with scenery in the real world being detailed and vivid. However, the visual highlight of the series comes from its incorporation of its augmented reality elements as characters are able to visit richly detailed virtual worlds with avatars they personally create (Kuroyukihime's avatar sticking out prominently here in both design and its fan servicy attire). The Brain Burst game renders the characters in armored avatars with differing abilities that are slick-looking and make for the best animated parts of the series when characters battle one another with a great amount of fluid movement involved in battles.


While sporting an interesting premise that I did enjoy some aspects of, Accel World does still stick firmly in conventional territory to a great extent, the stakes for the game felt rather underwhelming compared to other titles I've seen that featured MMORPGs or other technologies employed in any sort of serious plot and it ends inconclusively. You might get more enjoyment out of the series if you are a recent anime fan that hasn't picked up on many of the common cliches employed for anime as I have. But otherwise, I'm mostly indifferent to Accel World.

First of all, if you are a "looks- orientated" person, this is not for you, not only is the MC short and fat, his design does not match the rest of the characters. If you are not too overly bothered about looks, read on and let me explain why this anime is so heavily underrated. 
The first comments I see about this anime is about how people dropped it after seeing the main character, generic comments are usually "no way a beautiful girl could fall for him", "I can't stand watching such an ugly protagonist", "he whines about his life too much". However if youlook past that and look a little deeper, you will realize that this anime is very touching.


Put your self in the shoes of the MC, you are ridiculously short and fat (these people exist in the real world), you are bullied everyday by people who you know have better lives than you and you comfort eat because of it. The only girl you ever truly felt a connection to was stolen by your best friend, and you didn't even bother fighting for her because you knew you didn't even stand a chance against a normal, good looking guy who is athletic and smart. And yet, you still try to be happy for the both of them. His only escape from reality is playing squash by himself in a virtual world in the male toilets...now tell me that he has no excuse to be moaning and winging about his life. 


Then all of a sudden, you are introduced to a world where the pain and suffering you have endured for so many years is manifested into strength and courage. This beautiful girl falls in love with you for those aforementioned qualities and for once you feel loved in the world. 



This is the premise of Accel World, a story about how a guy finds happiness using the years of pain anf suffering he has endured, people often compare this to SAO for obvious reasons, but the tropes and meanings could not be more different. In fact if you are looking for type of anime where a good looking guy gets the good looking girl, go watch/read SAO.

TL;DR Charlotte’s Web. The Anime Ver.
Pigs can fly. And that’s a fact. Imagine the pig Wilbur saved by an intelligent spider, Charlotte who then turns his life around. OH WAIT, this sounds familiar. It’s Accel World! (Spiders and Butterflies >.>, semantics).
Of course, it’s not really as simple as E.B. White’s children’s novel, and to be perfectly clear, besides the spider saving the pig, it’s not even remotely similar. Read on for los detailes.
*Jump straight to Character if you have gripes about Haruyuki. So do I, and I even like this sow (o.O) *show.
STORY : 8
The premise of this series is surprisingly original. It’s the futureand everyone’s hooked up a global network. Via the implant in their neck, they can literally access the world wide “internet” and browse numerous files, play numerous games, and otherwise engage themselves in a VR (virtual reality) world. Complete with custom designed avatars and all the works. Our story here is about chubby Haruyuki who suffers from chronic depression and low self esteem. He’s the only chubby/physically unattractive person in the entire school of standard pretty anime stereotypes. This gives him cause to mope. (I would too, imagine going to a high school for supermodels.) However, in the virtual world, (in which his avatar is a pig), he meets the school’s beautiful idol, Kuroyukihime who introduces him to Brain Burst.

Basically an amped up fighting game that can reveal the secrets of the human psyche if you can clear it.

Not too much pressure for our main man is it? Well, the story, after introducing this unique setting, proceeds much along the lines of a typical shonen story. Boy then develops secret power, beats people, loses to people, becomes inspired, suffers personal losses, deals with demons, grows stronger, romance buds, etc. All well and good. And well done, and which is why this story works in terms of entertainment. It’s just fun. And fun to watch.


CHARACTER: 8.5

Ok, ok, people gripe about Haruyuki, and its legitimately justified. He’s basically Ouma Shu, but chubbier and has even lower self esteem, if possible. He thoroughly comes off as an uninspiring main character if you take him at face value. Besides the nascent fact that anime is not littered with fat MCs, much of entertainment serves to provide us with images of pretty leads and perfect (looks wise) people. Haruyuki is different, and normally you would say that’s great. Break the stereotype and all. But because he has Ouma Shu’s personality (at least at first), he’s thoroughly unlikeable. 

But wait, I still like him, and that’s because the second character, Kuroyukihime, his foil, his love interest, and the most interesting character in the show, allows the Haruyuki to move beyond an initial type of pathetic-ness. 

Kuroyukihime is everything Haruyuki is not, yet she’s attracted to him, don’t worry this is not  a spoiler. Why, and why is what Haruyuki asks himself. But there is no doubt, in the scenes between the two of them, there is undeniable chemistry and inspiration. I’ve not seen such chemistry between leads in a while. The romance between the two is always underscored by Kuroyukihime’s intensity and dry wit, it’s fun to watch. (And to bring it back to the Charlotte’s Web analogy, Kuroyukihime’s avatar is a big butterfly, (which is not unlike a spider >.>).

The other characters are also fine in their roles, the childhood friends, the enemies, the unlikely allies, etc, the personalities are pretty well developed and fleshed out. Character gets no complaint from me.


SOUND: 7.5

It’s well done, but standard. You have your typical fast BPM OP, appropriate music where it fits. Well done, but not transcendent. Good enough. The voice actors, I thought, were also decent. Haruyuki, smh, is voiced by Kaji Yuki, who voices Ouma Shu, but at least Haruyuki get’s past Shu’s stupid personality after the first 3 eps or so.

Kuroyukihime’s voice was decent, I actually enjoyed the deadpan delivery more than some other viewers who thought that for Misawa Sachika’s breakthrough, it was mediocre. Personally, calm, sometimes cold Kuroyukihime does have that voice. Even the emotional scenes in which the understated “baka” declarations come out, were in character for this role.


ANIMATION: 9

Production quality was top notch. It’s like Guilty Crown, but better. (Man, I seem to be bashing on GC quite a bit). GC’s animation still trumps AW, but for all intensive purposes, if the series is better as a whole, story telling, character, etc, then it’s better. That said, the animation was always fluid, character models moved well, the fight scenes superbly animated and cinematography done surprisingly well in certain scenes. (Usually where heavy emotion was involved).


ENJOYMENT: 9

Gripe about Haruyuki because I know I did. It was because of him that I put off watching AW for as long as I did. But once I took plunge, I found a deep, interesting, and dynamic show that manages to infuse the shonen genre with some much needed originality and difference. The romance, for once, was a highlight of the show. The chemistry between the main leads, superb.

*Some of you may see Kuroyukihime as a manipulative ice queen, and that’s plausible. But I prefer to look at it like Charlotte’s Web.

I am going to write the background of Accel World then move on to other things. Remember I am writing a review based on 2 episode of anime and 9 chapters of manga so it might not be in depth
Accel World is basically a cliche story about a guy and girl meet and suddenly super powers arrive. Although it is cliche many people likes this type of story and willing to watch them. For me however is the element of Sci-fi that made me like this.
Accel World is set in future Japan were the children are fused with computers. The Neuro link is basically acomputer stuck on your neck that is directly attached to your brain so that you can see computer screen within your eye. Not only that the school is learnt by teachers sending packets into the students head as shown in first 1 to 2 min.


Of course the animation shows the basic problem of the world. When there is a rule in place, there are people who evade them. The "social camera" is in place everywhere to make sure nothing bad is going on however bullies have a program to look for blind spot for them. Therefore bulling is not stopped for people like our protagonist. He endures it by going to a virtual world where full 5 sense are transferred into an internet world.


Story: 7

I like how they set up the background story but story itself is still cliche girl and boy meets, girl loves boy because of something, boy gets stronger to defend girl.


Art: 9

The art is great. Using the normal art for real world and CGI for virtual world, we can get the sense of change and have a good look at the good art styles.


Character: 6

They seem normal... nothing unusual except most popular girl falling for a fat unknown guy with all her heart. Reason? you will see, and it isn't very reasonable to me (but some people will say love ain't reasonable)


Enjoyment: 9

The battle scenes were very enjoyable. The little struggle and love comedy at the side makes this an interesting animation. Just wish they will do more than just 24.


Overall 8

Except the main idea is common this animation maybe amazing. The unique background (atleast in anime) where each person is a computer and the society completely accepting it is rare to see. Therefore I give this a 8

I'm going to make this short because well, I just finished watching the last episode and feel a headache from cheer stupidity coming on. 
The concept was interesting. The first half was better. The plot falls apart, the main character goes from annoying, to bearable to mind numbing infuriating. It never truly concludes and what normally would of been a couple episode long story-arc begins the entire second half of the season. 
For a show that keeps touting ideals about Haru being so awesome and so much better than he gives himself credit, he -NEVER- stops needing others to come saving him and wins purelyby brute force, intervention of others, and outnumbering the competition. 


The pointless fanservice went too far as well. Devolved into making all female characters pretty much just attractive meat to oogle at and was quite annoying as the character concepts were all interesting. The problems are never thoroughly thought out and all simply hand waved away and gets solved in manners completely unrelated to how the characters try and solve it as well.


The story, writing, and directing just does not hold up. Severely disapointing after coming here because it was highly recommended to those who enjoyed Sword Art Online. 


On the bright side, it is pretty.

I actually brought myself to watch this anime because of it's unique story and the concept of neuro-linker. I haven't watch too many anime with similar concept, so I have to say that I was content to watch it on overall basis.
But one thing bugs me though. If we put the brain burst and neuro-linker aside, this anime will leave us with a bunch of teenage with identity problem:
First, there is the main protagonist who is bullied at school and having a problem with his "real world". Seeks refugee in the virtual world, and even becomes oblivious of his friends. To the point that hemade one of his friend cries, a girl for that matter, and the other friend hate him because his girlfriend is giving more affection towards the protagonist. These problems could easily avoided if he is content of what he already has, and paying attention to his great friends in the first place, which is oddly enough this was shown in the rest of the story (for now I can't judge it as either for the sake of his retribution or his real identity shows up). I know this was maybe for the sake of story development, but I certainly don't think that it is the best thing to tell your subconscious to.


Second, there is the female protagonist who shows our main protagonist the concept of brain burst. She sure is an interesting character. But on the other hand, her curiosity makes her betrays a truce. A truce that were made with the rest of her mass. I understand the condition she were in, and her motivation. But she blames children naivety as her justification, that's what troubling me most. Don't get me wrong though, I didn't try to verdicts certain age for I am incapable to do so. But I think children's role is to LEARN. And adult is the one to SUPERVISE them while they were learning. As long as one need to learn, then they were children. When one is content of his learning and can guide others in the learning, then they were become adults, age doesn't matter here. At least that was my own preferences for this matter. And regarding her ability and her role, the female protagonist certainly an adult in the "brain burst" proposition. And to think that someone that I expect to be a supervisor would betray the mass out of curiosity and then make others follows her path and continue her deeds, that was way too much. If I were to have a child on my own, that is certainly NOT something I would teach them to.


Most anime I like usually has characters does something horrible for the sake of others, not for one own benefits. Maybe this is my own preference, but I can't stop myself to point this bizarre out.


Back to the matter at hand, I like this anime for it's excellent neuro-linker interface. And the crews certainly did their best to make use of these to build matching atmosphere. Such as, the interaction between character when direct link is provided. The explanation of brain burst and neuro-linker is itself interesting. I praise the art and sound for this, therefore making the whole anime itself more enjoyable.


This anime is adaptation from a light novel, and it has also adopted into a manga. But I can't bring myself to read those other materials as I still hopes this anime could "surprise" me more. By this time, there are only 7 episodes aired out of 24 in agenda. I personally hopes the story development will prove what I wrote in this review wrong. And if in the end it did, I beg you all a pardon. After all, that would be what "Not Helpful" button is for.

Hacked by Obara, Masakazu.

It's my first review so I'm sorry if anyone finds that I talk nonsense or if I accidentally offend someone.
Firstly, I just want to say that I absolutely did not like the main character. Not at all. The way he was drawn was just retarded and his personality is really... However that's the whole point of it because apparently, everyone in school hates him, that's how he got his awesome avatar, so yeah... I don't think the anime has done anything wrong in making him look like that.
So.. Setting wise, I found Accel World extremely unique and original. If i had to say, it wasthe setting that made me like Accel World so much. Not everyone can come up with a futuristic setting where everything is so advanced and cool, and i cant even imagine how hard it must be for the author figure out how to explain to the audience all the technologies being used so that it wouldn't be confusing. (Honestly, I am a really slow person especially when it comes to sci fi which is super hard for me to understand, so I think Accel World has really done a great job on that.) For the story, I thought it was really good as the way the different 'arcs' were introduced was appropriate and the solutions were nice, but I felt that Accel World didn't really make the motives of the bad guy so realistic. Just because the main guy's is 'different', everyone thinks he's all that? I really didn't find that so impressive as there are many other 'different' avatars but is it me, or is he the only one the everyone finds 'badass'.


For the art, the characters are really well drawn and really suit their personality. It is sharp and the designs of the characters really suit their personality (If you know what I mean) which makes it easy to remember the faces of the characters without striking hair styles and colours. The fighting scenes are really good in my opinion and the colours of the avatars make it really cool and colourful in fighting scenes. Though I wouldn't know what a good fighting scene is as Shounen isn't one of my favourite genres so excuse me if you disagree with me. However at some points of time, the art looks weird, like in between the episodes and the main character has to be one of the easiest character ever animated since he has no details added to him. It's like they didn't even try to make him look less.. Irritating. However, I loved how the artist drew the avatars and the fighting arena as it really brought out the whole 'game' concept which made the fighting scenes enjoyable.


The main characters are not bad. Having a fat, low self-esteemed, self pitying loser as a main character probably won't make this anime good based on it's main  character.  

Kuroyukihime seems like the generic 'bishoujo" reliable and perfect senpai that makes everyone looks up to her and you can't hate her because she's so perfect. However she can be really adorable sometimes, even though I have no idea why she fell in love with Haru. Opposites attract maybe? 

Chiyu is also pretty ordinary. The normal childhood friend who spends her time worrying about your social circle, just that she has a boyfriend (I know, weird isn't it?) At first she's really irritating, but after you get past all that, she's really adorable and funny.

Accel World has done quite a good job with the more important characters as by the end of the whole thing, you feel like you really understand the them.


However, the side characters are what makes the story more interesting.

Noumi is the most memorable character ever. I have no idea how anyone can even come up with him. He's a complete genius who comes up with these plans to wreck other people's lives (And not the good kind). But thanks to him, the main character isn't the worse character in the anime.

The side characters are really awesome and compared to other side characters are much more developed and talked about.


Overall I found Accel World a really enjoyable series and the fighting scenes were really nicely done. I recommend this to everyone and I think it would not be a waste of time. Unless you are really looking for a fantastic plot with extremely intense fighting, otherwise I think that Accel World would really be nice to watch. The story is pretty predictable and there are many issues regarding the main character, but I feel that the best thing about Accel World is the awesome Brain Burst Program and the cool futuristic setting so don't worry so much about the flaws and just try to enjoy the anime as much as you can.


Thank you for reading this and if you disagree with me, I am really sorry.

A Mixed Bag of Virtual Reality Mayhem
*note* I have not read the LN. I judged this anime based on its credibility as an anime alone and not an adaptation. *note*
A mixed bag is really the best way I can explain Accel World. While the production elements behind this anime were fantastic, there were scenes and character interactions in this anime that seriously made me groan. Let me start with what this anime did right.
The artwork/animation and music for this anime was fantastic. I thought Accel World has perhaps one of the best soundtracks of any anime I've seen in 2012. The OPs and EDs werecatchy, upbeat tunes that any fan of I've Sound would enjoy. The animation was simply outstanding, in fact, downright gorgeous. Accel World itself was visually captivating as the many environments within the VRMMORPG were great. I thought the character designs were also extremely well done with the lone exception being Arita. I'm not sure why because I know this sort of characterization had been done before in other animes, but I found his character design to be far too cartoonish for this series. I understand the animators were trying to make a character that obviously is short and chubby but even the facial design made it way too obvious.\n\n
I found this anime to be extremely enjoyable with how it executed Brain Burst and Accel World. My interest was extremely piqued during the fight sequences. Perhaps as someone who is a gamer as well as an anime fan can take some enjoyment of seeing such elements in an anime.\n\n
Personally, I found the story and character development to be rather weak...or at the very least, the weakest part of this anime. More specifically, there were sequences during this series where I screamed "WHAT?!" at my computer screen because the most absurdly inaccurate things would happen, especially in the latter half of the anime. There were also interactions between the leads that would make me groan in agony at just how unrealistic that sort of conversation would be and the implications it has toward the plot. Trust me, Chiyu had MANY groan-worthy moments in this series. Also, to be honest, Arita is not one of the more likable protagonists you'd find in anime. I don't mean that in he's short, fat, and does nothing but play video games. Hell, I'm completely fine with that aspect. I found the way he interacted with his friends at times to be completely unrealistic and off-base. There were also sequences that would happen earlier in the anime, emphasize that they are important, and then never really come back to them. Granted, they could come back to them in a 2nd season (which it was setup for) but in the meantime, peeved me slightly.\n\n
The best way I can describe Accel World is that it was a fantastic anime that had its flaws and kept it from being a fantastic anime. It's still a nice and a fun watch, but this series really underperformed with its cast of characters. Nevertheless, I'm still intrigued by the prospect of a 2nd season and if it can somehow manage to at least tweak some of the things the 1st season did wrong, I'd be ecstatic with the product Sunrise would be able to put out.

Hmmm I can't claim that I hardly rate anime a 10 since it looks like I have at least 5. But my initial reaction after having just finished the episode is that this anime, like all the anime I rate as a 10, does one thing, and one thing well: Tell a great story. Something that sucks you into a world, immerses you, losing all thoughts other than the characters and the plot. 
Accel World brought all the elements to tell a great story: the art, the music, the animation itself. The animation itself was really pretty as well as the character designs. Coming froma person that has not read the LN, and didn't know the events beforehand, watching this anime was an emotional roller coaster for me. The unique thing I found with this anime was that I found the guy characters cute and funny as well. They often times brought a comedic effect that often times helped lighten the very dark and depressing themes in the story. Although sometimes those same character made me wanna slap them a couple times myself from the view of their own self-worth and hurting others from that. I found myself laughing with them and crying with them, and being happy with them.


From the cliptime spent with each character you could tell it was important to the staff to spend just enough time to get the emotions across. I could feel the TLC. Noting seemed rushed. The music did a very good job of supporting the story and suggesting the desired tone at the moment. The art and fight was very well done. Most of all though, I loved how they developed the characters and the time they spent with each. I'm sure to someone who has watched the LN it might feel rushed or maybe even totally skipping out on relevant backstory or arcs but for me I felt they spent just enough time on the character and back-story to really observe these characters as all struggling with their own hopes and dreams and sadness. Time was spent when they cried, when they were happy, when they laughing. I really felt that they spent just enough time for someone watching to really start to empathize with these characters.


The only downside, I would say is the distaste with all the characters having dark pasts and insecure but I think it'd be unfair to say they were one-dimensional characters. The other reason I rate something a 10 is because whether you end up not liking the anime or not...it definitely is something worth watching to see for yourself. Hands down.

Accel World is a very interesting concept, and had great potential. Unfortunately, the characters and their motivations are illogical, annoying, and hypocritical. The initial concept of the game the characters play makes sense initially, but as the series goes on the game logic becomes clouded and muddled to the point where things just stop making a whole lot of sense. The main character is a fat loser, which was pretty unique at first, but I never really felt like he was a fat loser. He thinks he's superior and when he beats somebody, tells them he's superior. There's some sort of love triangle thing Iguess, but it's confusing and inorganic. None of the characters presented feel like people, and I actually found myself hoping the good guys would lose because I hated them so much. But the anime does look really pretty, and the show does have its cool moments but overall the anime is quite mediocre. I wouldn't really recommend watching this.

Like most anime the sound/art was good but the story enjoyment and characters all nose dive about ep 16.
For the first 12 eps if you can deal with the major plot hole that the main character is a short fat beta and chooses his online avatar to still be short and fat then you will enjoy the story and how it progresses at a steady rate introducing new exciting topics. The problem comes with the second half. They spend a whole season on what should be at max a 4ep arc and all other parts of the story go very slow and leaves many holes.(the manga probably solves these but I haven't read it)

This anime is one of those that have a great idea and have a good storyline to back that idea. So in other words it doesn't disappoint. With fantastic art styles, and solid character development, it makes this anime quite an enjoyable experience. Despite the main character being a disappointing fail for most, the anime does a good job making him grow and develop in the virtual world and also the real world. He transitions from being a person with low self esteem who lets others take advantage of him to a somewhat more mature character who learns to stand up for himself and hisfriends. Basically this story  shows the life of a nobody in the real world becoming a somebody in the virtual and also the real and with him realizing that, thus enabling him to seek his full potential. Overall this anime is worth watching, with a wide range of characters with interesting personalities and a great concept of futuristic virtual gaming in a dramatic way. During this anime some of the episodes may get a bit trivial to the main plot but yet it still makes for a well executed episode regardless. I enjoyed this anime series because it was well done in all aspects and it is very vibrant which makes up for the poorly designed ( avatar not included ) main character with a some what negative personality.

This anime has a lot of good and bad things about it. For the most part, I liked the anime but there were things i just couldn't get past.
Some good things:
1. I love the futuristic VR gaming world that Accel World creates. While it's been done a million times, at least they don't mimic SAO or .Hack
2. The psychological aspect to this anime is also very likable. Watching how the character's personalities become submersed into Brain Burst was an interesting look into how games can actually have an effect on people.
3. The art designs for avatars and landscapes were well thought out. They were allvivid yet solid in their concept. \n\n
Some bad things:\n
1. I hate how no matter how powerful he gets in the game, Haru always berates himself even though he brags about how he became more confident because of Brain Burst.\n
2. Didn't care for the generic "Loser meets perfect girl" scenario they set up. Especially since their character dynamic as a couple doesn't develop AT ALL.\n
3. Usually, a good villain is defined by their intricate back story that led up to their evil action. Noumi takes everything I like about villain dynamics and throws them in the trash. He only exists to make Haru suffer and piss off the viewer.\n
4. Like most anime adaptations, there isn't enough all-around character development. Chi would be a perfect example. She didn't spend a lot of time with taku because she was always worried about Haru.He means the world to her (which pissed off taku) and splits up with taku but still treats Haru like a child.\n\n
There are a lot of things that were wrong with this anime, that are typical of many anime I've seen. The only things that make this anime redeemable are the art and theme. Was kinda pissed when the season ended being all about Haru vs. Noumi

Accel World is probably one of my most favorite SciFi 
Why? Simply because I enjoyed the story and its uniqeness in every aspect.
First of all, I like the story. Personally, I really like the idea of a kid being a main protagonist, and how he changed himself and the people with him for the better. I learned the imprtance of true friendship and other stuff. Only sometimes, I just get irritated when a character in the story loses hope and becomes negative. But having a good positive outlook afterwards is what I like too.
For the Art, I think its outstanding. I just liked how creativelythe characters and their avatar were drawn. I felt the SciFi within the drawings.


The Sounds, I like all of it. The OP and ED songs were well matched. The soundtracks for Action parst and Drama parts were perfectly fit. I like the casting for voice actors/actress too.


As for the characters, I like the characters. But its just that I'm just a little disappointed because the protagonist is unrealstically fat and small, sorry, but I'm just a little bothered by it. But I still think that that concept was for the sake of the show.


Enjoyment... Hell yes I enjoyed watching every episode of it. To the point that when I am outside, I will shout, "UNLIMITED FULL BURST", or get my USB wire and connect it to my friends' necks.


Overall, Accel World is indeed on of the best SciFi. I personally recommended it to some of my family members, and some of my friends. It is must see if you wanted this type of genre.

First review, so cut me some slack, please. Note: I haven't read the manga.
Story: 8
I like the story, even if it's not exactly unique. I give it 8 since I'm not entirely sure of the motivations behind each of the main characters. Also, I assume there will be a bigger rival then the wannabe Ghost Rider and the bully, although it'd be nice if they came back and did something to try to avenge their defeats. Since this big rival hasn't been introduced yet, I can't give this any higher than 8. 
Art: 9
Good art style. The character design is pretty good and Chubby-kun looksadorable, in my opinion. The battles are pretty damn good too, although the lack of an OP and ED with the first double episode leads me to believe that quite a large chunk of the episode's budget was spent on them. I expect the fight quality to go down in the following episodes, but this is a 9 for now.\n\n
Sound: 5\n
No OP or ED in these episodes, and I'm not really a big fan of the two songs being used either. The rest of the music was just decent enough.\n\n
Character: 10\n
I really enjoyed the characters. Chubby-kun is someone many people can relate to, and his pig avatar seems perfect for him. I wonder why he chose a pig though. Maybe I missed it in the episode, but I'd think that in a virtual world, wouldn't someone with low self esteem create a cooler looking thing? I'd like to know the reason for the pig, but it definitely fits his appearance. He also has room to develop, unlike a lot of other characters, and his development could really mirror that of a real human being, as he tries to raise his self esteem and confidence.\n
Kuroyukihime, meanwhile, is superbly illustrated and I'm grateful they didn't exaggerate her figure. If I remember my own days in middle school correctly, unlike in anime, girls there generally didn't have a 36 DD rack. She seems to genuinely care for the kid and wants to actually help him out. She definitely has ulterior motives, but she did everything in her power to give him a chance, which tells you she won't be the stereotypical "cheerleader"-type.\n
Haru's two friends, meanwhile seem pretty interesting too. The girl is nice enough to get him food and the guy seems like he's willing to help him as well, although he might become jealous of the fact that the Chiyuri seems to like Haru. This may turn into a problem for Haru later on.\n\n
Enjoyment: 9\n
Typical of it's genre. I am a bit biased towards anime such as this and generally enjoy a good animated fight, so this is a 9.  \n\n
Overall: 9\n
While the technological aspect of this story is a little overused, it's refreshing to see a main character that I personally (and I'm sure many, many middle schoolers in the United States in particular) can relate to. I was Haru when I was that age. Of course, I managed to grow out of it in time and without the assistance of a pretty girl (debatable). At the moment, I'm liking the where this anime is headed and I like the message it's presenting a lot: Find something you like, that you're good at and that you can share with other people, and even the pretty girl who you have absolutely no chance with will at least notice you. Considering what's happening in the world today, with the sheer amount of bullying that goes on in our schools, this anime couldn't have come out at a better time.

I don't usually watch the seasonal animes of the year and wait for them to finish. I did this with Accel World. Accel Word is created by Reki Kawahara the same creator of the light novel Sword Art Online, which was also adapted last year. The popularity of Sword Art Online was very high and lots of the Sword Art Online fans will say that its better than this series by only watching one episode. I have to say Accel World is a much superior series compared to Sword Art in story and character. This series tell the story of Haru and is set inmore of modern futuristic city where everyone has holographic screens put in their face to click certain options and crap. He is fat and often bullied in school this all changes when he meets Kuroyukihime the president of the school. Over the course of the series he attracts a lot of females much like Kirito only he makes it quite clear who's with instead of completely ignoring everything that's happened. She installs the program brain burst which is a virtual reality world. Quite frankly my theory is Sword Art takes place years before World but eh I could be wrong. With the game comes the supernatural ability to slow down time to the point it looks like its stopped. If you lose a fight in the game you lose burst points lose all your burst points lose the memories of both accel world and lose the ability to go back forever. So really compared to Sword Art Online there was more of a suspense with that. The show picks up pretty fast right when you think its going no where and has lots of plot twists. I have to really recommend this to anyone who watched Sword Art Online it really is a good show and you'll enjoy it a lot. The only problem I have with this show is a problem I have rare with any show is that its to short. It should have had more episodes to explain better back pasts and the setting of the virtual world a little more. You'll find  similarities in both Kirito and Haru a lot as well but this is due to Reki's writing style in my opinion. Its an amazing show. Its a show I actually wanna re watch. Its a solid 8/10

It's my first time reviewing an anime, so please bear with me...I was actually wondering why Accel World was rated so low but now I completely understand...  I hurriedly watched it because I was addicted to SAO and was wondering the connection on why Accel world was rumored to be a continuation of what happend after the whole SAO plot .Furthermore , I know SAO was a bit overrated and lacks some story elements .. but it was still enjoyable and the characters ( Kirito and Asuna) seems to save the story( as for me) ....  I am a  big fan ofadventure and romance anime and SAO really hits the spot...but this one.. I truly,madly, deeply hated it..\n\n
[spoiler] The lead girl is the only thing, I liked about the story.. It was obvious that she has connections with Kirito or even Asuna by the whole rumors going around the web... All of it make sense because the anime even hid her own real name ....(Why don't they just reveal it earlier since everybody already knows and the fact that at the epilouge  it was an open end question) The author and anime already gives many hints about her real identity..... Somehow, everything can still be handled but what drag on is the main guy.. Seriously, how could you watch an anime when the main guy looks chibi, constanly cry, and has almost no good point.While watching, it was so disturbing that he was the only one drawn in that way... If the author wanted a bullied person that turns into a hero, he could still have done it with a reasonable figure not a 4 feet tall roll of melon.. It was so lame that the girl even fell for the guy without a very valid reason .. It does not make any sense just thinking about it makes me wanna puke...[/spoiler] I like SAO much better... It dwells with the same problem as fate stay night... the prequel did better than the sequel ... It was so nerve wrecking too watch that such anime was a "continuation" of SAO. If I were the author, I would rather have explored on the story line of the main girl rather than adding the main guy in the story. :( It was a major let down for me!

Before I started watching this anime, I was very skeptical of the anime by the anime cover art. Then again its always the "never judge a anime by its cover". So I took the chance and unfolded the story of Accel world.   
After the first three episode, I was already intertwine on how Accel world worked and the concept behind it is marvelous. Although it isn't your typical action/ fantasy anime it had the lush of something similar to it. You would call it, romance/action/slice of life/fantasy/comedy packed into one. That is something I haven't seen in a anime in a while. 
Whatstood out the most in Accel World is the character development of almost all of the main character. From start to finish, it seems like almost all of the character had a major change through the anime. Each one had its uniqueness to it and the author capitalized it excellently.


Accel World fell behind ultimately on the art. Although I usually don't discriminate on the art, I got to say that almost every girl in the anime had blushed or pink cheeks. That is something that is obvious and obvious. The art overall is not on par with current anime but it did not fall behind much. 


The ending faltered a lot of plot holes but it opened a possible squeal. Potential is what see. Hopefully a squeal is delivered as I enjoyed much of it in Accel World. 


Overall:

8/10

The upsides of this anime are the artstyle, which is pleasant but not challenging and the soundtrack, as it occassionally contains quite catchy and/or epic tracks. 
The story itself isn't something special but what makes it situationally hard to watch is the degree of romantic tension between the chubby main character and every other female in the story. It's absolutely unnecessary to constantly emphasise sexual attraction between the lead and his female best friend (in a relationship with his best friend) as well as with the elven year old little girl he's friends with, it's just another (creepy) wish-fullfillment for the target group "overweight andsocially isolated". 


Accel World would have been a decent anime if they focused the energy that was put into fanservice into a bit character and story development. And it would have been good if they additionally had reduced the amount of time spent on solely repeating things the viewer already knows or can easily guess. 


In it's storytelling premise and shortcomings it strongly resembles Sword Art Online.

This is one of those shows that someone pushed me to watch.  After watching 3 eps, it grabbed my attention, but not enough to push me to continue.  Now, almost two years later, I finished it.  This should not discredit you from watching this at all.  What originally caused me to not be hooked was that this type of show or the sci-fi aspect of it is not something I normally lean towards.  That being said, it didn't take long to make me binge on it and finish the show in three days.  I could write a long drawnout term paper to describe all of the reasons in detail that you should watch this show, but I will try and sum it as best as I can.  


- If you ever dreamed of being able to run, jump, fly, or simply defy what your normal self can do, then you will find excitement.


- If you have ever understood the pain of being bullied, being told you are not good enough, or even felt sorrow or depression of losing someone important, then you will find companionship.  


-  If you have ever felt the pain of betrayal or the sting of losing a close friend, then you will find the courage to seek redemption.  


This show takes all of the pain and negative things the world has done to you and shows you a way to move past your scars and bad memories.  It shows that you are never alone and that there are people who care for you if you only allow them to be there.  I cannot express enough how this series reminds us that we should never allow our pain to define us, but rather, how it should redefine us.  How we should use it to empower us to reach potential in ourselves we never knew we had.





"A scar is a sign that something is missing, something important to you has been removed, leaving a hole in your heart.  Having that empty hole can lead to anger, hatred, or despair, or it can do the opposite and push you to reach higher"

I will begin by stating that I only started watching this show after seeing some of the fights on YouTube and thinking "Wow, that was intense". Was I impressed? Sadly, no, but I haven't finished the show yet so I may be revising this review later. The reason I'm making this review now is because if I force myself to watch another episode without taking a break and venting to you poor readers, I will end up hating and dropping this show... Which isn't something I want to do with this anime. Here's my take so far...
The story line is actually quite nice. It's gota simple goal, reach level 10. Quick and easy. The setting is a futuristic version of Japan where just about everything is monitored digitally. Everyone is hooked up to a global network through Neural Linking devices on there necks. They use these in place of computers, phones, Ipod's and just about every other entertainment and communication device. The show itself often takes place in the "Accelerated World" which is part of a game called "Brain Burst". In this game you fight and level up to obtain burst points which you can use to cheat in the real world. The highest level that is referenced in the show is level 10, which no one has ever reached. That about sums up the story.


The art in the show is done flawlessly(... Other then the main character...) and the fluid animations are what drew me to the show in the first place. It takes a bit for you to reach the episodes with the good fights, but they're well worth the wait. The designs of all the avatars are really intriguing to say the least. They look like human sized Gundams that were smashed together with Tron outfits to forge a look that's quite creative and variable, allowing every character to have there own truly unique appearance. Outside of the virtual world are your basic cookie cutter mold characters, though they are still fantastic looking in 1080p XD. 


The soundtrack was enough to get you pumped up in a fight, which is to be expected, but other than that it didn't really stand out. The sound effects where everything they needed to be so there isn't anything missing from it, but they certainly didn't add anything special or exhilarating.


Now for the part that brought this show down to a 7 from 9... The characters. All there personalities are as cookie cutter as there appearances. They include all your typical characters from other anime copy and pasted to this shows shallow selection of inhabitants. All the relations and bonds seem forced, and the only ones that feel somewhat natural are the bonds between Haru, The main character, and his friends Taku and Chiyu, which you don't get to see the forming of since they're already friends when the show starts... And even then, there relationships don't seem to make sense. The only character I liked is Chiyu, and that's because she's the only person who knows that games are supposed to be fun. Everyone else makes the game out to be some sort of alternate reality where any wrong move could spell the end of there lives... All that, and I still haven't touched the subject of all my rage and disappointment... THE MAIN CHARACTER!!! His nickname is Haru and he is a pig shaped short kid who looks, acts and feels completely out of place. Everyone in the show states repeatedly that he's this loser who's a master at video games and he's the fastest gamer they've ever seen. But they never show anything to prove those accusations. He spends 95% of the time being awkwardly unsocial, dimwittedly thick, and incapable of performing the most basic of actions efficiently with any sense of logic... His problem solving skills are unbelievably lacking for someone who's supposed to be a gamer, let alone the fastest gamer. It's like they wanted him to relate to the nerd population, but had no idea what nerds where like. The reason a loser is good at games is because they're not a loser in the games, only in real life, where their body can't perform the badass things they're capable of in games. I'd like to add that scientific studies have shown people who play games are 37% less prone to mistakes then those who don't... Ok, I need to move on or I'll be at this forever.


I do enjoy the show, even if it is dumb a large portion of the time. Many shows are off balance because the main character becomes too overpowered so fast that any resistance from the tasks put in front of them becomes trivial. Other's make characters who remain just as strong as in the beginning so they can overcome the trivial tasks with moderate ease and then complete the moderately difficult ones with slightly less ease. This show throws you for a loop by giving you a character whose so obnoxiously inept he can barely accomplish the simplest of tasks without getting beaten like a rag doll even as he grows stronger. He gets his ass kicked by people who are just as pathetic as he is, only to spontaneously defeat impossible odds by defying physics and his own character traits to take down some guy that was made out to be really strong, much like himself, but turned out to go down like my ex. Then spontaneously go back to being completely inept... well I guess he was just as inept when he beat the silver giant dude who will not be named for spoilers sake, he only won because the story demanded he be temporarily strong enough to defeat that guy no matter how out of character... Wow, I started that up again... Was it worth watching? Yes. Will I keep watching? Probably. Do I hate Haru? ... Very much so... How do you fail posing as a Loser/Nerd? He found a way, which I guess makes him the greatest loser ever and thus perfect for the role...


7 OUT OF 10!!! I'm out...

This next part is an edit after watching 2 more episodes of the show. I can't take the show any more, I'm dropping it's score to a 6 and subsequently dropping the show on my list... Its turning out just like bleach, with the occasional badass fight thrown into a show about really dumb and inept people failing to keep me enthralled with the story... Chiyu started taking the game too seriously, just like everyone else... Just... To much stupidity for me.

6 OUT OF 10!!! I'm out for real this time T_T So sad...

Before you say a thing JUST BECAUSE THERE's a FAT GUY in the Picture and is the MAIN Doesn't Mean it SUCKS !!
So Here's my Review For "Accel World" This is made by the same Author Of SAO and of the Same Universe, but Doesn't Have any Total Relation With The SAO arc well I'm Having Doubts about that you'll Feel the same when you've watched the Series.

Its also gotquite a great love story for those who chases romance in anime's so I gave it a 10, As for the Art Is good I gave it a 8 the way the drew the characters is Original didn't even copy any names (that I know) So the char. is 8.\n

So Accel world seems like a very good anime, the thing that is amazing is that it is one of the first animes that fearture the main character being fat (or tubby) it kind of reminds me of a Hack, but features PvP fights rather than role playing that Hack setting is surrounded by.

I am absolutely appalled. Accel World is, without a doubt, the worst anime I have ever seen. Written by Reki Kawahara, the same author as one Sword Art Online, Accel World is an ugly amalgamation of everything wrong with the modern anime industry and should serve as a clear example of what not to do when attempting to create a work of any artistic value. 
First, let us dive into the characters. Our main character, Arita Haruyuki, is an obese and bullied junior high school student. He is also the center of his own personal harem, where the most popular girl in school and avariety of others lust after him. You have to ask yourself why this is a thing. Does he have a dynamic and charismatic personality that can't help making all the girls around him collectively swoon despite his physical appearance? No, not quite. Instead, the reason is something I like to refer to as "awful writing." Our main character himself is blander than the chalk I attempted to choke myself with after getting halfway through the show. You'd think the fact that he is constantly bullied would lead him to have some sort of resentment towards those around him, but instead he is your typical white knight wish fulfillment mc. Gotta believe in your nakama desu!!! Not to mention, he's the chosen one who can never lose!


The rest of the characters are none better, as they fit perfectly into various tropes such as the childhood friend, sexualized loli, and perfect upperclassman. The characters also never develop throughout the show, instead making complete 180s in personality whenever it's convenient for the plot. Poor writing, character development; Tomato, Tomatoe; am I right? XDDD


The premise itself was quite promising for the time, when MMORPG anime didn't populate the industry wherever you looked. However, execution is poor and you need to have a certain suspension of belief to empathize on any level at all. All these characters are 15 years old or younger, and you want me to believe that they're mature enough to do even a third of the things that happen within the show? Stakes are at an all time low, where the worse that can happen is that you can no longer play the game. This completely nullifies the purpose of any in-game conflict, and anything that happens in real life will be ass pulled 100% of the time. It also suffers from FMA syndrome, in that every character has some sort of tragic past for no reason at all. One of the characters even has PTSD. They're 15 years old, for god's sake. 


Art really isn't worth mentioning. It's your generic budget harem stuff, and when in game is your choice of dreary background so they don't have to spend money designing a variety of places. Nothing notable here, but nothing quite awful either. I commend them on the use of CGI for health bars and the such, but that's about it.


All in all, don't watch Accel World. This show is bad.

Ever wanted to be faster than anyone else in this world? Keep the fantasy going as you watch this anime. Accel World, as from its name, allows one to accelerate faster than other people in that world. 16 minutes 48 seconds in Accel World is only a mere 1 second in the real world! Imagine how fast you could actually be...
Story :
I’m assuming that you’ve already read a little about this anime so I’m going to dive straight into this. The concept of this anime is really one that truly gave me a “ WTF” moment. I mean, moving faster than anyone else in aspecial world, as if manipulating time in your own hands isn’t something I would think of in a regular basis...Thus, the concept of this anime was undeniably a really catchy.  To be really honest, when I first started watching this, I was like, “Awww come on! It’s just a multiplayer duelling game! How in the world did this get so popular?” However, after watching a few more episodes, I spanked myself for how foolish I was. This was not only exciting but it was interesting and somewhat motivational to some. Almost every episode was action-packed and heart-pumping which got me glued to my chair even though I cannot sit still for long, watching episodes after episodes non-stop, resulting in me finishing this in a mere 2 days. The 2nd part of the anime however was somewhat draggy because of the number of episodes dedicated to character development. Some episodes even seemed to have completeyly no link to the main plot. Maybe it was their plan to go through this development for us to understand the later plot. It was only towards the last few episodes where the action aspect of the anime begin to show which wasn’t what I wanted, considering the fact that they could’ve just reduced the episodes dedicated to character development and maybe focus more on the fight itself. Still, I honestly love this story!


Art :

Quite a commendable art work as almost all characters are beautifully designed, having a natural blush on their cheeks every moment which was kind of cute to me(I’m no pedo...). Not to mention, the duelling avatars are all very funky too. Many people, though, have complains about the lead character, which I would focus on the next section. 


Character:

“OMG! THIS GUY IS SO FAT AND UGLY!” “I didn’t want to watch this anime because the main character is fat and ugly” Alright, I’ve had enough of these comments from my friends. I’ll be honest. I had this exact same reaction too when I was planning to watch this anime. Until I watched the 1st two episodes did I finally know why Haruyuki Arita (Lead Character) was designed in this manner. To put it simply, the duel avatar in the game was crafted based on one inferior complex. Thus it is a must for him to posses such an inferior complex in order for his avatar to be strong. Just a really brief comment on him. He is always being bullied, afraid of things and thus escapes to the virtual world where he is the best there. Kind of pathetic at first sight. His partner, Kuroyukihime in contrast was smart, popular, beautiful and enjoys status. Perfect? I’ll leave you to find out yourself if she’s really a perfect girl.


Sound:

Superb openings & endings. Catchy and impressive. Never skipped any one of them until the anime officially stopped. The OSTs are as impressive any well. Some OSTs give you a tense feeling as you heard it while others give you a soothing and relaxing feeling. Moreover, the sound effects the duelling avatar emits is really really cool. I cannot stop commending how impressive the sound effects were. 


Enjoyment:

Really enjoyed it considering the fact I was willing to stay up late just to satisfy myself with just one more episode even though I do not have the habit of doing so. It made me forget everything around me and when I finished the anime, I then realised I was literally “living” in this anime for 2 days. Got me into the chuunibyou mood whenever I finished a epic scene which is kind of embarrassing as I’m 16 years old right now. Would strongly recommend you to watch this anime as I am sure most of you would enjoy this action-packed and heart-pumping anime. 

Thank you~

Amazing. Beautiful. Stunning. These are all words you could use to describe Accel World. In fact words don't do this review justice, thats how much I enjoyed this show. AW was one of those shows where I HAD to come back each week to see what was gonna happen next. It kept my interest from start to finish. While it had its faults, the series as a whole was (to me) one of the most addicting and most amazing experiences. I warn people though, this IS NOT an anime of just ONE focused genre. Part of what makes this anime so good is that ithas many different themes and genres that make the experience great. Many will say they hated the show and give it a super low rating and others will give it a super high rating, its all about preference. Some of the many genres that pop up frequently are Romance, School, Drama, Fighting, and above all Sci-fi. Some people go into this hoping for only one main genre but I personally don't think you can enjoy this without having at least some interest in those multiple genres. And if you have an open mind you'll enjoy it even more!


Story: Well our story here is set in the not-to-distant future, where society is almost fully computer integrated. Everyone wears these mobile computers around their necks called "Neuro Linkers". These devices create virtual reality (HUD and you can "Dive" into a fully virtual world on your local network). Our MC, Haru, is picked on by almost everyone for being small, fat, and a loser. He is approached one day by the most popular girl in the school and she shows him a world beyond reality, a game called "Brain Burst". This game turns out to be so much more because it allows its users to speed up their minds (slowing down time) and in some cases speed up their bodies. Users can choose to use this power for good or evil. But there is one catch, its use is limited by your "Burst Points" and in order to gain BP they must continue to fight in the savage place known as Accel World!  Now I could go on all day explaining every bit of this story but my words alone are not enough to do it justice. The story is filled with ups and downs, hardships, overcoming obstacles, friendship, love and inspiration. The story is as complex as you want it to be. 


Art: Well there isnt alot to say here but the artwork is really top notch. Very well done, animations are smooth and very exciting to look at. During alot of the fight scenes I'd stop and rewatch certain parts just cause it was so badass! Wonderful design of the characters, Avatars, and environment. The visuals often added to the feel of the characters or setting, which is common but great none-the-less.


Sound: WOW, the BGM in this show blew me away! Everything from the fighting music to the emotional music. It was all above and beyond what I hoped for. Not many animes have given me that feeling where I have to rewatch a 30 second scene just for the BGM. And the Openings and Endings had amazing music! This is the ONLY anime I have ever watched the OP/END scenes for EVERY episode. 24 ep. + 4 OP/END = Some really badass and enjoyable music.


Character: Well alot of people have very strong opinions here. The main character is fat and actually really pathetic at the start of the show, he really does make great improvements during the show. Alot of other characters make you want to throw your computer out the window (Thats how well the author makes you hate them!). Some characters you just love so much and fill you with joy when you see them. This show is focused around middle school students and does a great job of portraying how middle school students would act. I think this show does an excellent job of evoking feelings with its characters, and thats part of what makes this show so good.


Enjoyment: Well if its not noticeable already, I am in love with this show! I stumbled upon this show because of boredom and im really lucky I did! This show is about video games and the future and school, and that appealed to me. I really felt this show was something special. Im not saying everyone will have this experience, but I know there are many who will. 


Overall/Final Thoughts: This show is meant to be realistic while staying sci-fi. Some may hate it, some will love it, many will enjoy it. The way the story is told and its characters is just awesome and it has a very "real" feeling to it. The music is to die for! and the art is superb. All of this is only my opinion and above all else I recommend you take the time to try it out, the show only gets better as it goes on. The last episode left me with an amazing feeling, hopefully others can feel what i felt then and all throughout the show!

I often find it's difficult putting a numerical value on things that seem so difficult to quantify. Often, I can find myself enjoying a TV or anime series immensely, but when the time comes to put a number to the past 6 hours of my life, I struggle. In this particular case, if I think about it, the quality of each of the different elements is not earth-shattering. On the other hand however, and this is probably the biggest reason why I would recommend this anime, irrespective of why I enjoyed it, I did. 
I found myself emotionally invested with the characters, regardless of howdeeply flawed some people believe them to be, and I was on the edge of my seat a few times throughout the season. You can rate anime and you can rank it, but at the end of the day, we all want to look back on however many hours we've just spent watching that particular series and judge it worthwhile. With Accel World, I firmly believe this is the case.


Very briefly, here is my breakdown:


Story: 7


The story is compelling for the most-part, and in sections very well thought through. It does however succumb to a bit of predictability in parts. There is the spark of originality in this anime's basic premise, and I found that to be quite refreshing. The whole "VR" sub-genre often challenges our concept of reality, asking questions such as "what happens when technology can effect our minds?" and "how far can we go with this?" 


Art: 7


Nothing particularly special, but I have a fondness for Accel World's style of animating fights. I find that as the screen gets less clustered, and the colour darker (night-time for example), the art can be beautiful, and I appreciate it.


Sound: 9


Two endings, two openings - four great songs. "Unfinished" is one of my favourite endings, and the piano build-up to it at the end of each episode sends a shiver down my spine.


Character: 6


The biggest problem with this anime. I want to repeat however that enjoyment, as well as how much I like a certain character, does not equate to rating. While I adore Kuroyukihimi more than I can describe, I cannot rate the complexity, the depth of her character, the intelligence of her design, particularly highly. I realise that she fits the mould of "harem girl" as well as "powerful female senpai", and regretfully admit that she isn't a feat of character design. However, the playfulness common to some of my favourite characters is held by her.


Haru's love of crying and his appearance is a little off-putting, but his heart's in the right place, and I don't dislike him as much as some people seem to. He is somewhat of a cliché, a classic anime character, much like Taku.


Enjoyment: 9


I've made most of my arguments previously, so I'll just repeat that I adore this anime, and enjoyed it despite its flaws and holes. Kuroyukihimi is my waifu, and I'm dying for a second season. 


Give it a try, it's a good anime.

It's always fun to see how people envision the future to be like. With the possibilities of technology continuing to increase, it's no wonder many individuals have their minds set on a technologically-driven future. Focusing on a rapidly-rising feature in the gaming community, Accel World seeks to depict what it means to take the "virtual" out of "virtual reality", albeit at a limited level. If one's life were to revolve around a video game, what would it be like? Let's see the results of this interesting premise.
Art (7/10)
I'll be honest here. I really dislike Haruyuki's character design. It's not so much that he's fat, butmore so because he's so disproportionate to the other characters. Given that he's the essentially the poster boy for the anime, this isn't a good impression to give. But aside from that, I thought all the other character designs looked quite nice, although they were a bit on the plain side. The background details of the show were on about the same level. The most memorable animation aspect was definitely the battle scenes, which should be expected from an anime of this nature. For the most part, the animation for the fast-paced fights filled with flashy attacks was smooth and of decent quality.


Characters (8/10)

Let's first take a look at the main male protagonist of the story, Arita Haruyuki, whose character has managed to more or less evenly divide viewers into two distinct groups of fans and haters. On the surface, he is indeed different from the usual anime characters—fat, short, and whiny are just a few of the negative adjectives that have been used to describe him. And while people are entitled to their opinion, isn't judging a character based on his/her appearance a bit superficial? Upon further analysis of Haruyuki, you can see that he grows a lot throughout the series. Although his transformation is not so much a 180-degree turn, that is what makes it realistic. The other characters also display signs of growth as the series progressed. Through the difficulties and trials they experienced—including battles with past demons and encounters with antagonists—all the major characters ended up noticeably changing for the better.


Sound (7/10)

For the most part, shōnen anime are rarely driven by great BGM pieces or talented seiyū—and Accel World is not an exception. Both the aforementioned aspects did their jobs well, but not to the point where they were memorable. For me, I found that the OP and ED were the best parts of the show in terms of sound, but that's not really saying much. All four tracks are upbeat to a certain extent, sharing a common synth feel. Everything was quite average overall.


Story (6/10)

The idea itself was promising; integrating gaming elements into anime generally produces good results as quite a number of viewers are also gamers. However, execute it unsuccessfully and you have a subpar story at best. Although learning all about the Accelerated World, Brain Burst, and like was interesting at first, it soon got to the point where things started getting either repetitive or uninteresting. Overall, the story moved at a slower pace than I expected, and at times, felt bland and boring. However, it did have its moments in which it was able to earn my praise. Nonetheless, the slow pace of the story, in my opinion, is what hurt its score the most.


Overall (7/10)

Accel World is really just your typical shōnen anime. You get your typical "weak at first, strong at the end" protagonist, a bunch of high-octane battles, and some good dialogue. If that's your cup of tea, then by all means give it a try. But if not, I'd suggest giving some thought before watching this show—24 episodes is quite the time investment—though that's not to say it's a bad show. When it comes down to it, the enjoyability of all shows comes down to the viewer, some more so than others.

Finally, an anime about MMO game done right, not only the show managed to put a lot of detail into the fictional game mechanic, it also managed to put a very high price in "losing" without falling to the usual "you die in game you die in reallife" niche. 
The major fights are really well executed, often time the main character have to rely on tactics and strategies instead of raw power. The cast are likable, the vast size of the game world mean Accel World going to be a really long ride (so far the novel have enough material to cover 3 24 episodeseasons.


Each story arc keep pushing you to watch the next episode, I found it really hard to stop watching without finishing an arc. As the story progress, more of the world will be slowly introduce the viewer. By the end of the season, the viewer will recognize that the show only covered a really small part of the world. 


Of course, the show also come with its flaws, the worst offender is the obvious harem. And yes, it'll get pretty big, of course some people might consider this to be a plus. For me, it is disappointing that instead of having a deep meaningful relationship, a lot of rich characters got dumb down into the harem as the show progress. 


Regardless, Accel World is one of the best, must watch show of 2012.

The story itself seems very interesting and thought out. The character's have been thought out and well rehearsed. The only thing i don't like about Accel World is the main character. I honestly do not enjoy characters that complain and whine every other minute about something. I prefer a more head strong type of personality.
