I realize that you can't take very seriously some guy who gives an anime a perfect 10 - you'll probably call me a fanboy, or some such tag. But let me tell you: coming off of my post-Code Geass depression, I've been finding shows that embody what I wanted from Code Geass, and even more. Accel World captures action, humor, art and romance (though unexpected) perfectly - each is balanced in a way that maximizes the show's effect on your heart. It got me over my Code Geass depression (though made me more depressed once it ended - oh well, can't be helped). This showwill not be a waste of your time - and at 24 episodes, why not give it a try?


Take for example the plot line (which I gave a ten... whoops): Code Geass has a wild, confusing plot, due to Lelouch being a (criminal) mastermind. This makes the plot very interesting, and never lets you down by stacking up surprise after surprise. Accel World's plot is less about the complexity of the character (although Arita, Taku and Kuruyikihime are very intelligent players) and more about the complexity of the world they are in: the game that seems to think for itself, and is continuously throwing curve balls at the players. In this way, it is harder to estimate the outcome: you are familiar with Lelouch's mindset and personality, and can somewhat assume what he's up to, whereas you cannot necessarily read a game's facial expression.


The art makes me want to cry, it's so good. The only thing that bothers me is that they threw away their amazing talents on Arita - he really is... well... un-handsome, if possible. But then again, that just serves the character better. It is easier to understand his hardships with such a vivid visual. Apart from him (and I commend the team for making such a gross sprite) Kuruyikihime and the rest of the cast is beautiful. It screams ANIME, and the duel avatars are also amazing.


As for enjoyment, this is not your one dimensional show: while it might be an action show, it is HILARIOUS. My parents kept walking into my room after hearing me squeal, and being like "You okay there?" The sexual tension between Arita and basically every single girl never gets old, and his constant antics make me laugh. Also, Kuruyikihime's cool humor caught me off guard a couple of times. And don't forget Chiyu! 


This show is a must watch! It's only 24 episodes, so it will only take a few days out of your busy schedules. Give it a shot!

I was sick over a span of 4 days in bed, i was desperate for some entertainment and had picked up Accell World after 22 episodes had already been released, needless to say i was pretty hooked and managed to watch them all within 2 days.
The main character Arita is so frustratingly annoying, his default expression are these eyes of sadness which thoroughly annoyed me through out, from what I've read he has single handedly made people drop AW in the first few episodes. His appearance is obviously a code for his timid and weak nature as he is the first character I've seen thatis so short and fat, he looks like a shorter chubbier version of Simon from Gurren Lagann except he also just sooks ALL THE TIME, someone compliments him and he starts crying, he get s a piece of cake and he starts crying, he wakes up most likely crying, it's frustrating but at least the anime holds so many positives that i could get over this.


I like the Concept of the brain blast program that allows people to fight in an MMO style game where they battle to try and keep enough points to 'burst link' in the real world, it basically lets them cheat on tests and be better at sports and stuff making life a lot easier.


once in the brain burst game, users take on avatars, meaning i can look at  Arita's awesome avatar the 'Silver Crow' instead of him, the fighting was really well done but i wish Arita would stop sooking during fights, it's like he cries and then gets the motivation to fight again after, i preferred the gurren lagann style where they would just get really pumped up about fighting spirit and all that stuff which got you as a viewer pumped up as well, sooking is just annoying as a viewer when it happens every fight.


There's a good deal of twists and double crossing and all that good stuff that make plots very engaging and dynamic. especially the later episodes when the villian Noumi is introduced, AW did a fantastic job of making you hate him, he's a young brat trying to manipulate your much loved main characters which infuriates youa s a viewer, i wish i could crawl in my monitor and beat him up which means he was very well represented as a villain.


I would highly recommend this anime, it had a good blend of action but it's biggest flaw is it's main character which is a shame, if you can get over him (which is easy since the positives are so many) you'll really enjoy it.

Accel world started out really well, but ended in an annoying and clueless fashion.
All of the characters are well-defined except for Haruyuki. He literally cries every other episode. If someone close to him dies, then I think it's okay for him to cry. But he cries every time he turns around.
The alliances and history behind the Brain Burst is interesting, but the anime is not complete and leaves a lot of questions unanswered.
The stolen powers arc was practically the second season and Haryuyuki cries even more. The villain in that arc is repetitive and made me almost stop watching the Anime. I deducted Character andOverall just for him and Haruyuki.

From the get go, Accel World is a series you kinda just have to press the "I believe" button in your head to understand. Sure it's in the future and yes it's an anime, but as far as making the world something that feels natural and smooth, it's completely different.
-Story-
The story of Accel World is that of Haruyuki Arita and how his miserable life is changed by the Virtual Reality game "Brain Burst" and a girl known as Kuroyukihime. The premise of the story itself is interesting enough to get people to try out the series, but the way the story progresses is one ofthe flaws of this series. It has it's sessions of high speed progression then slows to a dull walking speed where it seems like it really can't make up it's mind.


-Art-

Easily one of the most impressive looking animation sequences of it's season, it stood out graphically among a string of high end animes. The scenery in the series is impressive enough to make you want to use still images of the series as wallpaper.


-Sound-

I never found myself mesmerized by the soundtrack of the series and found myself skipping through the intro and outro every time. The overal composition and track list isn't impressive enough to me personally to make it memorable in any way, but it did succeed in not making me want to mute the audio every time I did play through the music.


-Characters-

This is where the series fails in my eyes. The story is solid, the art is amazing, the aura of the series is robust. The most glaring flaw of the series however is the characters. For the most part, it's hard to relate to the characters and the relationships within the series seem unnatural. Believing that well developed characters make a story able to write itself, it never felt like the characters made the story but rather the story made the characters.


-Enjoyment-

There are plenty of good parts to the series that make it worth at least one play through. There's enough action to make most people happy and enough fan service to keep the pervs happy.


-Overall-

Overall, I felt like more could have been done to better this series. The first couple episodes were slow, the first 1/3 of the series was great. After that, it slowly went down hill for me. It's well worth at least one play through so if you haven't seen it yet, at least give the first 5 episodes a shot.

Synopsis Overeview
In the year 2046 the virtual reality is used for almost anything. And Arita Haruyuku (our little chubby hero) is amazing at games, never the less he is in the lowest scale of his school being constantly abused by other students and thus constantly cries about his miserable luck.
But everything changes when Kuroyukihime, the most popular girl in school introduces him to “Brain Burst” a virtual reality program that grants him the power to stop time, at the same time it gives him an avatar, which he has to use to win battles, and win points, and that’s the catch: If he happens tolose all his points he will lose the brain burst program, and all the memories of ever having it (which in turn means he would be returning to his miserable life).\n
Evidence for:\n
As a shonen anime, is not surprising the battles are very well made, and the plus Sunrise was the producer, is not a surprise to see such an amazing animation, meaning: The battles and the Avatars are plain amazing, with the diversity of powers, dynamic movement, and amazing design. And this also applies to the “real world” animation, though some characters might be something you don’t usually see in this genre (like A chubby little guy being the main character, and his best friend a first badass then whiner still popular guy).\n
Evidence Against:\n
Even though Accel world shines in the art an animation, it lacks everything else: All the “Power of friendship” and “You must stand to stay strong” cliché is a little overused. Plus the characters are plain, bland and a bunch of whiners (most of them).\n
On the other hand, the plot as it is, doesn’t give any sensation of risk. Even if you happen to lose all your points, you don’t even remember having them in the first place and (as shown in the very last episode) the traits that you gains with the game (courage, sensibility, or anything else) stays with you, so what ends good… is good right?\n
About the OST, thought very epic is usually subdued by the constant yelling and crying of the characters, or by the same sound effect on the battles. Making it easily forgettable.\n
Overall:\n
This anime truly shines in its graphics, but the plot, the characters and the sound don’t live to it.\n
Characters: 2\n
Story: 4\n
Art (and animation): 10\n
Sound: 3\n
Personal enjoyment: 5\n
Overall: 4.8->5\n

A lot to say about this show but I will try to keep this review short and quick. I believe the first few episodes of Accel world carried the show. Meaning that the world of Accel world was so enticing that even though the story line of the show may have been non inspired, you still were willing to finish out the show based on the strength of the first few episodes. At least that's how I felt. 
It seems that a lot of people didn't like Haru's attitude and look. However, I really related to Haru in a lot of ways. If you knowsomeone or are someone with low self esteem, you are able to say that Haru was not exaggerated at all. Definitely a lot different than his sword art counterpart.


Story:


This is the weakest aspect of the first season of Accel world. Like Sword Art, Accel World is able to create an entire world during the few episodes. This is a new world of battle, friendship, rivalry, and defeats. I was very excited about the potential of the possibilities that could arrive because of this game, rules and character. 


However, these expectations were not met. The first half of the series was okay, the purpose was to mainly get some characters introduced, and understand more about the game. Around the second half of the show is where things really took a turn. For the worst.


The main villain has to be probably the most annoying person that I've ever heard or seen. Every time I heard him speak, I cringed. He had no rational motivation for what he was doing, and his power (in the game) was just too freaking too much..I won't give spoilers..but I really didn't like this villain..and the arc just dragged on and on..it was so tiring and was the ultimate downfall of the first season.


I could go on and on but I'll stop here


Art:


The art is beautiful, I was captivated by the backgrounds and the new world. When Haku started flying for the first time, I was in awe of the scenery below him, it was really well done.


The character design were really well done, everything looked really well and fluid. The animation is a high point in the show.


Sound:


I also like the background music, it fit most scenes perfectly and I think this is a ost worth getting.


Character:


I like Haru. Yes, there were moment where I facepalmed at his actions but overall, as someone who doesn't have the highest self esteem, I really related to his sentiment shared in the first few episodes, having people look down on you because of your looks. Being so ashamed and believing that you are inferior to others and don't deserve good relationships...I don't share those extreme feelings but in a way I could related. And unless you can, I doubt that you will like Haru.



I also like Kuro, she's intelligent, confident, and caring. She has some very nice characteristics about herself, and is enjoyable to watch. I was kind of wary about her intents first on the show since I just couldn't believe how quickly she fell in love with a fat chubby "loser" but her sentiments are real and she's legitimate.


I don't care too much for Taku. He's really really generic, and doesn't really bring any substance to the show. He also doesn't have that much potential to be that interesting unless he self sacrifices himself or something. I don't care too much about his relationship with Chiyu.


Chiyu is interesting, I liked her until she got too nosy and started to want to involve herself in the game. It would have been better for her to stay away from it, in my opinion. I think that like Taku, she's a bit generic but at least she has a really good character design and not all of her actions are that predictable.


Enjoyment:


I enjoyed the first half of the series a lot, but not so much the second half, I wish that the story line was more inspired and really went deep about the content and mystery surround burst link..but none of that happened.


I still think the show has potential so i look forward to he second season.

i'm not really a sci fic fan, but i'm open to ideas and usually give diff anime chances. but being a big romance fan that pretty much will watch anything with it in it i decided to check this series out.
as you've probabaly noticed, the main character of this show is drawn as a short chubby guy that has 0 attractiveness on the outside. but don't let that bother you.
the overall story has alot potential. it exceeded my expectations and 1 season doesn't really do the whole show justice. the big story was just beginning after 24 episodes. i'd see season 1 as a goodintro to characters, and get you to feel out what Accel world is about.


character developments do happen, but it doesn't happen at the fastest pace, but like i said season 1 still has tons of story that is waitin to be continued ( next season)


if you are huge sci fic/fantasy/romance fan i'd recommend you checking this series out. even if you are not you might still want to consider giving it 3 episodes. maybe you'll discover something you might grow liking.

In my opinion better than the first season of SAO.
Access World is about this fat middle school student Arita aka Haru as he plays this game called Brain Burst which is an app he got from Kuroyukihime. His avatar is called Silver Crow and he later finds out more about the game as the series progresses. The interesting thing about "Brain Burst" is that if the user loses all of his/her burst points the app is deleted instantly and the user won't be able to re-download the game. In addition, the user would forget the existence of the game as a whole. In the beginningHaru is a victim of bullying and can't do anything about it until Kuroyukihime helped him by getting the bullies suspended. After a series of events Silver Crow gains the ability to fly and is the only people in Brain Burst to have that ability. After the first half of the season the plot focuses on a character called Seiji Noumi who blackmails Haru into giving him his burst points so he could help his friend Chiyuri. Seiji's avatar is called Dusk Taker and it's ability is the ability to take away another user's ability or weapon.


There are some good character relationships in the show, but the best is the relationship between Haru and Kuroyukihime. Now I'm not going to spoil anything, but what she does to him in this show is a testament to how much she loves Haru.


The one notable character I could remember off the top of my head is Seiji. He is just a despicable character and a really good antagonist.


The voice acting in Accel World is great. I really enjoyed the dub for this show.


I overall loved Accel World. It is has everything I love in anime from it's characters, story, animation, character relationships, development, and ending. Speaking of endings Accel World has one of my favorite endings in an anime. It was a very smart ending that made sense and it caught me by surprise on how good the ending was. The only thing that makes me cringe is that there is no season 2 to this amazing anime.  If I had to give my two cents, this show doesn't disappoint and is highly recommended to watch.

Accel World is a very good beginner anime and some what mainstream. Accel world is about "The year is 2046. Haruyuki Arita is a young boy who finds himself on the lowest social rungs of his school. But that all changes when Kuroyukihime, the most popular girl in school, introduces him to a mysterious program called Brain Burst and a virtual reality called the Accel World." This anime is very similar to sword art online and log horizon.

A typical video game anime, but it did have an insecure main character and he grew over time which I thought was nice. I thoroughly enjoyed the action though.
Let me just say that the first half of this anime was VERY boring and I had trouble watching it. It did pick up andthe last half was better. It does not excuse the fact that the first half was very boring. I do like to see incompetent characters grow, but they have to make it interesting. The ending villain was pretty bad too. Overall the anime was pretty good. The action was good so I enjoyed that and I liked most of the characters, but I didn't like how the main character was so dependent on others. What an amazing but yet unexpected experience.
Where do I even begin with how much I actually enjoyed this anime. I guess the best way for me to sum it up is that it is a perfect example of an anime that has every character archetype that you can think of with a very basic and easy to understand plot but these things did not hamper my enjoyment of this anime. Despite falling prey to typical things you would see out of most anime that would take place in a high school/adolescent setting they actually did a great job of making the characters likable, the storyenjoyable, and the pacing steady and consistent to the point that this anime was actually quite addicting to watch.


In this anime you have an unpopular and supposedly unattractive high school student that gets made fun of because of his looks so he sinks his time into online games to help him deal with some of the depression he goes through. This all changes when an attractive girl in high school gets interested in his talents in online games and asks him to be a part of this game called Brain Burst. He is unsure of all of this, and thinks he is being used but the two eventually develop feelings for each other throughout the course of this anime but the overall core of this story focuses on this game and his evolution as a person into this game


The story that revolves around this game is really what makes this anime incredibly enjoyable. They build up a great story inside the world of this game and the constant battles that take place. The action in this anime is top notch and I can't say that I was never bored while watching this anime. There were no episodes that were needless filler and there was literally the right amount of story progression with each episode. They spent the first half of this anime building this online game world with a very interesting premise that focuses on the main female lead of the story and her desire to be the best player in this game but it comes at a tremendous cost that a lot of other players don't want to even entertain that thought.because it may ruin what makes the game enjoyable for so themselves. I really wish they kept to the overall story arc of the first half throughout the entire anime because it seemed really interesting but by the time they got to the second half.of this anime they changed tactics a little bit when they decided to focus on a villain that made the main characters lives very difficult and unbearable and unfortunately because of that the main essence of over-arching story had to take a backseat which is a bit of a crying shame because I wish they would of elaborated on it more because it would of made for some really excellent battle scenes. However, the second half of this anime was still enjoyable because they made the villain incredibly easy to hate and despise. Thankfully the fan-service is kept to a bare minimum.


The action is what made me really love this anime. All the action scenes were really good in this anime and probably some of the best I've watched yet and they evened out the action with the character building and story telling really well. Fights did not last any longer than what was needed and the characters regardless if they were protagonists or antagonists did not overstay their welcome. I also have to admit that the music for this anime is really good. Both opening songs and the first ending song have made it into my anime playlist.


I think overall the best thing about this anime is that its a perfect example that sometimes things didn't need to be overly complicated for it to be good. The anime is a little bit like .hack but without the philosophy and the preachiness. You have an awesome online world where players battle each other with a wide range of special moves and abilities. The designs for all the different characters in the online world are amazing.


Overall this is a really good series that I got quite addicted to very quickly. I hope we get a little more of the accelerated world beyond just a film and a few ova's which I'll eventually get to.

This anime is like Pizza that’s been left outside for about 24 hours—not quite a steaming pile of shit but not something that I’d recommend ingesting either.
 At its core, Accel World is a mediocre MMORPG, mini-harem, shounen. It’s a tale about a high school loser, Haruyuki, joining a sophisticated VR PvP gaming subculture. Playing this game allows one to slow down time in order to PvP battle, but also lends itself into manipulating real world situations. In addition to gaming for the sake of gaming, Haruyuki follows his stubby little c*** into the “Accelerated World” in hopes of winning the favor of his crushand helping her achieve her goal of becoming the ultimate high ranking player in the game. 


The mediocrity is strong in this anime. It lacks character development and contains many cliches and stupid plot lines. It ultimately fails to be much of anything beyond a waste of time.



Clichés vs Rules:

A cliché is born from lazy, unimaginative writing. It copies something that worked in another setting and clumsily pastes it onto the current one. One example of this in the MMORPG anime context is giving the protagonist a super special in-game power that nobody else has. We saw it in Sword Art Online with Kiritu’s Beta-testing head start and his *ahem* special power pertaining to swords. We saw it in that Dungeon anime where the wimpy protagonist leveled at x10 or whatever the pace of everyone else. Anyway in Accel World we see the same shit where Haruyuki’s character gets a special skill that lets him soar above competition. Convenient, right?


Rules are just basic, genre-specific facts that are necessary to the plot to make sense. In this case, it’s a rule that MMORPG anime should have real world stakes. Imagine in Sword Art Online if the solution for escaping the SAO virtual world was….*Drumroll*….Logging out?!?! Holy shit man. Boom. All the suspense, urgency, purpose etc. would evaporate. In SAO at least the anime characters were as trapped as the viewers of that shitty world. Accel World it’s just a game. If you lose all of your points you’ll just no longer be able to play that game. No Death, no brain-melting retardation, you just suddenly have a lot more free time to devote to homework. You have these faux emotional scenes were Haruyuki freaks out when he sees his friends slaughtered in the game and you can’t help but roll your eyes. NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO! DON’T DIE!!!!!!!!! Then the match ends and they get ice cream and talk.


The unforgivable part of this anime is that they hardly explore the amazing real-world uses for their ability to slow time. Everything is about leveling up and getting a stronger character not robbing banks or setting world records. The conflict in the anime is just juvenile and ultimately uninteresting.


Romance Angle: Props for making the main character legitimately physically unattractive. None of this good looking, tall, athletic but can’t seem to get a chick archetype. Haruyuki flat out looks like an Anime Eric Cartman. That being said, their unconventional character design makes the all-too-familiar cliché of having the school’s hottest girl throw herself at the MC even more ridiculous. Really? The class president/hottest girl in school/academic prodigy/Miss popular etc gets all hot and bothered watching this chump play virtual squash with a piglet avatar?!?! Fuck! I feel cheated by my high school experience. But seriously, the romance subplot is just lazy and irritating. There’s no chemistry and she does all the work.


Character development is absent. 

Animation is acceptable but not great

Sound meh


Overall: It’s painfully clear that I’m too old for this. Ignore my opinion if you want and enjoy the rancid Pizza.

First things first. I extremely enjoyed Accel World and the characters in it. The show is very well written and all the characters, for the most part, are all relatable and believable in the story. 
Addressing the main character's design. Haruyuki Arita's character design is not shit. His design is a reflection of his trauma and his scars. He "unique" appearance is merely a visual symbol of the isolation the character has with the rest of the reality. So, his design is actually quite well done, and cute looking. Besides, you should judge a person on how they look. Haru's character is very deep andgoes though alot of evolution throughout the show. \n
He's a good character, and discrimination the show, just for his looks, would keep you from experiencing this wonderful story with these enjoyable characters.\n
Now, the ending. Without spoiling it, the ending of the show, while good, doesn't complete the ultimate plot of the series. This is due to the fact that the story continues past the anime in the light novels (which gets even better). But, though more support, Accel World will see a second season. \n
Overall, This show is amazing and deserves more attention. If you like scifi, good characters, and don't mind a technically unfinished plot, this is a definite watch.

“I don’t really want power; I just want to teach you to enjoy the game instead of taking it all so seriously.”
From the producer of Tiger & Bunny, arrives another brilliant blend of CGI armour suits. It is colourful, engaging, and entertaining. Accel World has a futuristic setting where The Sixth Sense is commonly used in society; people can dive into networks with their avatar to socialise and more. In a game called Burst Link, known only to a few, characters duel each other to earn points. These points allow the users to accelerate their thought process in real-life, obtain advantages in anything and everything.
Whatmakes this virtual world captivating is the Lord of the Flies, no adult, no rule, canvas. 15 year-olds or below have formed policies and have taken territories in the Accel World. Split into 6 factions, each led by a level 9 King, players fight to complete the game by becoming level 10. Plan and implement strategies, set traps and backstabs make some great turn of events. Fights include 1-on-1, tag duel, faction war, and free-4-all. Each faction sought to recruit players with special or rare abilities.


Referred by his classmates as “that round thing”, our protagonist is a coward.  Haru’s only escape is “Direct Link” to this virtual world. The protagonist is the biggest threat to the viewers’ enjoyment of this series. He can be as hateable as Shinji from NGE and he has the looks of Morty from Shaman King. The fear of being looked down upon by others prevents him to bring out the best of his abilities, who easily allows his spirit to perish. One exception to this is that Haru is willing to give everything to protect and fight for his King, the girl he falls in love with.


The characters might appear shallow at first, but each one would reveal more about themselves as the series progress. The characters are stereotypical, and their character development might be labelled as predictable. However, the execution was well done and although the characters can be extremely irritating at times, with the sudden turns of events both on and off the battlefield, their actions can make you change your opinion of them very quickly. New characters are introduced often to spice things up, creating problems as well solving problems.


The art is colourful and bright, animation is smooth and fluid. Sparks and other lighting particles are a bonus. The opening song is rejuvenating, and the soundtracks change to set the mood, blood-boiling techno in fight scenes which varies in relation to the stages the characters fight on; bright or dark tunes can be heard for their respective scenes. Fanservice include panty shots, shower scenes and grabbing breasts, not too excessive. A negative is that characters sound more mature than their supposed age.


The characters’ virtual Avatars are not as detailed as they could have been, considering the use of CGI. It would have been better to have the designs less rigid, less android, but more erratic and free-flowing. It would have been rewarding to rid of such restrictive metallic armouring that many Avatars have in keeping to the mecha feel, having said that, we do see some better designs that are more freestyle, which give the artists more room for creativity and fun.


The fight scenes are reasonably well done. Lots of fights are long ranged; those that are in close quarters tend to be a bit rushed or are animated in black flashes. The build-ups to battles give a sense of anticipation. When characters tell a story, it feels like I am going to learn something new and very interesting. The suit-upgrades, new power-ups, and new attack moves make me eagerly wait for the next act.


Themes include trust, betrayal, romance, and jealousy. Although, the series is set in a school environment, majority of scenes take place out of it. This makes the school affairs interesting when they do happen, and the change of surroundings makes the world more believable. Accel World has a fantastic concept. It could have made itself more unique by expanding the concept of territorial wars, in both the virtual world and real-life (which it tries). Behind the avatars and their elevated fights in this virtual game, laying all your honour to fight without regret is the essence of what Accel World conveys. If you want to see a colourful and entertaining shounen in a sci-fi setting with hints of fanservice, this is a great series to go for.

Story: 6/10
I'm going to start by saying that I have not read the manga for this or played the VN if there was one.
The plot line for Accel World was a bumpy road for me. It was really all over the place. The first episode was nice because it really pulled me in, but then from there to about episode 5 there was really no action and it was all talk. It bore me up to the point where I actually dropped this series while it was airing. I only decided to pick it up because I'm on holidays and wanted something recent to watch.Anyways getting back to the story, I'm just going to be honest and say that I didn't like it. While watching I felt bored and felt like I was just watching it because I wanted to finish it, not because it was amazing. Usually the first season is the one that attracts all the viewers, but if Accel World ever gets another season, I have a feeling that I'll enjoy it more. If there's anything that this story lacked, it was action. For an anime called Accel World and which is all about accelerating, you'd think there would be more action. I'd say it was 90% talking, 10% fights. The fights weren't anything inspiring either.. I found myself predicting what would happen numerous times.


Characters: 6/10

Being an anime about a whole virtual world, there were tons of characters introduced. There still remains several unrevealed back stories especially for one of the main characters, so at the end of it all you're still left with tons of questions. There certainly were a ton of characters that just disappeared throughout the story and could have used some more screen time. I don't really know what to say, I just feel like everything was poorly planned out. There's so much darkness.

Even though it was 24 episodes I felt like I only watched 5.

The girls were OP and the guys were wimps. In the future I predict it'll be the opposite though. But for this particular season it was saddening.


Music: 6/10

I didn't particularly grow found to either of the two opening or ending songs for Accel World. I feel like music didn't suit the videos or the anime. The background music was also sub-par, I can't even remember a single tune even though I just finished watching all 24 episodes in a row. It was plain and random.


Art: 8/10

The art was nice, and the girls were cute ^.^

That's pretty much what got all the points.

The boys however.. tsk tsk tsk..

I can't say that there were any "cool" male characters that aired in this anime.

It was complete female dominance. Not that I have a problem with that but..

Seriously, all the girls were OP and the guys were helpless wimps. Of course they're going to become stronger in the long-run but for this particular season it was unfortunate. The background art was okay, nothing really unusual or striking/notable.


Overall Enjoyment: 7/10

My overall feeling at the end of Accel World was, "meh". It was good, but nothing amazing. There wasn't a single time where I had that feeling like, "OMG I CAN'T WAIT TO SEE THE NEXT EPISODE" it was all.. meh. Whenever suspense would build up, it would always end in a mediocre way. I should have just continued watching it weekly because I kind of feel like I wasted my time with this. At the moment I wouldn't recommend this anime to anyone, but I have a small hope for a second season that will be much better. There was so much juicy stuff that was left out and waiting to be revealed and I can't wait to see that.


FINAL RATE: 33/50 (7/10 on MAL)

"Meh" anime. Wasn't amazing. Felt like a waste of time, especially being 24 episodes.

I dropped it while it was airing for a good reason I suppose.

In my opinion, all the good stuff that I wanted to see was left out and unmentioned for now...

HOWEVER!

Tons of potential left for a sequel that could make all of this worthwhile.

Hopefully the manga-readers are enjoying it, because the rest of the story is what I'm interested in.

First off, this series IS NOT FINISHED! Well the anime is, but it is an adaptation from a manga so it has that "anime done read manga next" feel to it with an open end. That being said, the story was NOW getting really good. 
The animation is great, the battles visually EPIC and the coloring was beautiful. Even the drawings of the characters were satisfactory....I mean they were pretty and cute, hell even the main fat guy character was attractive (i don't mean that in a sexual or wierd way....usually when anime draw fat character they make them HIDEOUSLY GROSS...few animes have drawnattractive fat people....this show did it well). 


The sound was EPIC....the battle music was really well done that you got drawn in.....perfect synchronization; voice acting was also excellent and the OP and ED (both) were nice....including the videos that went with it.


Now for the characters and story. The plot is interesting. Ever since Hack// a good few animes have been trying to adopt a virtual reality plot, many have failed...some succeeded. This succeeded. The characters are basically Kuro-Yuuki-Hime (black snow princess) whose real name nobody but Arita knows. Arita...fat self-loathing but okay protagonist (little hint of annoying at times), Chi-chan (surprisingly cool character except for the second arc where u kinda wanted ta kill her until the last episode where u were like "OOOHHHH, DAMN...WHAT SHE DID WAS EPIC...5 stars for her") and Takku who despite starting off cool, became a GIGANTIC TOOL for about 2 or so episodes, then returned to being one of the most likeable characters and comedy relief "THE PROFFESSOR". The cast is kind of steriotypical...i.e.e they aren't innovative...it's the normal "COOL SENPAI/LOVE INTEREST WITH WICKED POWERS", "CHILDHOOD FRIEND/LOVE INTEREST" and "CHILDHOOD/BEST FRIEND/RIVAL". But they did have some character development, very little in the way of kuroyuukihime unless you count her development of falling in love....but I don't really see that as much for her. Arita's self confidence is a bit annoying, his manner of giving up and doing nothing at times gets you annoyed, BUT when he gains resolve it can be REALLY EPIC, and well...the guy could stop crying like ALMOST EVERY DAMN EPISODE. Taku was annoying at first, he then became cool, and loyal and important. He was actually funny to see at times for being the "brain" of the group. Not much was done for Chi-chan in the first half of the series, except for her obvious love for the main character while having a boyfriend already. I MEAN SHE WAS PRACTICALLY BEGGING THE DUDE TO MAKE A MOVE ON HER...in the ending episodes (21 or 22 or something) she literally ASKED FOR IT...sorta! She was likable enough, and her role in the second arc was important, her method of carrying it out was EXTREMELY ANNOYING, but well the last episode really redeem her....or I should say *SPOILER* she didn't really need redeeming at all *SPOILER END*.

The show was a romance/harem....although harem isn't the actual genre it would fit into, the main character had 2 girls gunning for him, with a few other "POSSIBLES"...and he was fat/short.....which makes it UNIQUE for this genre. That being said, it focuses a lot on the action, the bad guy for the second half was REALLY detestable which was a GREAT thing....and the development for both Arita and Taku was done quite well. 

The PROBLEM however was this show is part of a long running shonen series....what I mean by that is, it has way too many things TO BE COVERED to just be 24 episodes, making you feel EXTREMELY INCOMPLETE. The romance aspect could be pushed aside since that is SORTA KINDA RESOLVED THOUGH NOT REALLY YET SATISFACTORY, but the action and the story development WAS NOW GETTING STARTED. Because of this, the show could have gotten a 8 or even 9/10...or depending on how great the story developed maybe even closer to 10 itself BUT since it was incomplete it CANNOT get more than a 7...and that's being generous. ONE LAST THING....PPL CRIED TOO MUCH IN THIS SHOW....


That said....I recommend this series as definite watch....not collection material, but something that SHOULD be watched as it was GOOD. IF there is access to the manga, then I suggest reading the manga instead IF the manga is anything like the anime (didn't read the manga so I don't know....but basically if the manga is a continuation of the anime then it is better to read the manga).

Accel world, the anime that ran parallel to Sword Art Online, shares the same manga creator and also the same universe in different time settings - Accel World staging a few decades after Sword Art Online. While there are no connections in the story line's, I feel that the author has a plan to connect the two. I hope that is how it goes.
Now coming to the anime itself, there is a sure sore reason to avoid watching it for many people - namely being incomplete akin Claymore and so many other names that come to mind. However it ends well - more like Claymoreagain, ending at a sturdy arc rather than leaving things totally open like Deadman Wonderland graciously did.


The story is well done - it, for me has a concise plot that has been defined in the first few episodes and all that is left for the story telling elements and character intrusions to define the anime. The setting is futuristic of the believable nature, not the super cyborgs or flying spaceships type, a big plus for me. Now what made it an enjoyable anime for me is that it connects story line elements well, most episodes themselves have a connection to the main story unlike Cowboy Bebop where many episodes can be considered from a standalone point. They give background but such that is relevant to the over all complexity of the universe. Not saying Cowboy Bebop lacks due to that trait, just saying I find it a plus in AW.


It has its share of light comedy moments, serious events and action, neither of the three overdone for me. The procession at certain points is certainly a little hasty for my taste however it does not compare how Sword Art Online messed up and it dismays me to see Accel World rated as it is.


The plot points were very intriguing for me, they build tension and there was a fair share share of plot twists given the length of the anime. There were of course a few shounen elements but for me they weren't that big a distraction. So, alongside the disappointment of no sequel, I felt satisfied in having watched the anime.


Art was good. The colors were bright with shading well done and shadows handled well, the scenes were crisp and beautifully depicted. The character design's were good - other than the main protagonists who seemed too far off believable proportions but the other characters stuck more or less to proper proportions and those proportions thankfully did not vary with camera angles.


The fighting sequences and the stages affiliated with Accel World itself were GOOD, each had its own ambiance with details properly handled and fighting sequences were equally well handled. There kept the fights flashy and vibrant resorting to style rather than the comparatively realistic scenes one witnesses in Requiem for a Phantom. Just to add a note, realistic fighting sequences can be tantalizing like in Shigurui - at least for me.


The sound also came as a big plus since they felt synchronized with the scenes, they reflected the mood at the moment and were not just fillers in the background. That for me made the anime quite enjoyable and added a certain charm to it.


Now before I comment on the characters, I'd like to say that if I based this around whether I like a char or find him/her pathetic then it would be a different story however I will judge whether a character makes sense, is defined properly with their traits believable and whether they are crafted as reflections of typical Shounen characters with no additional originality or have something good. To give an example I found Mayuri from Steins;Gate a... well not a well crafted character.


But I'll say it bluntly - the main character is pathetic, reminds me of Amano Yukiteru from Mirai Nikki which is not a good thing. Haru lacks self confidence and considers the situation from a pessimistic way when the matter pertains to any positivism related to him. However that is justified and while I hate such personalities, the traits are believable - there are people very similar to his personality.


The rest of the personalities fit well in as well - they each have certain traits to them, sarcasm, humor, manner of speech which make them not very interesting characters but in no way is that boring. They do have unique traits that make them stand out yet not too much. So over all the character development is well done - you see them not only as a couple of repetitive notions of justice or goodwill but see them in a broader light.


One another positive that relates to the art as well is that there are no super endowed women in the anime and especially the main females in the series are just... fine in that manner.


Over all I enjoyed the anime a lot - it kept me wondering what will happen next, got me angered, not as in making me hate the anime but making me anxious over how the story proceeds which is a good thing since animes rarely get me anxious. In the end I was wishing for more but not disappointed as I was with SnK. There were few draw backs to it that I wouldn't want to discuss since they will give spoilers.


So for people who like gadgets and are into networks, hacking and a little futuristic stuff, it is a really good anime if you can just accept the protagonist.


Hope you like my review and feedback is always welcome!

Accel World, an anime adapted from the light novel of the same name. Many people quickly dismissed the anime due to the main character. However, the the world of Accel World itself is so fascinating that it's unfortunate if you miss this.
The story is set in the future, where people are equipped with very sophisticated neuro link device that augment their reality. Due to the technology, it can also modify all you 5 senses an put you in a virtual world. Think Google glasses meets The Matrix. The story dives into an unofficial fighting game called Brain Burst that allows the players to be inaccelerated state. The tech concept by itself deserve some attention. Outside of the tech, it's the feel-warm kind-of story with typical themes like friendship, trust, not giving up, etc, with sprinkles here and there as pointers for the doujin community. ;-)


At least for now, you have the weak but cute and persistent main character, the loli love interest, the good looking best friends (with one turning into a handsome megane chara). Either you love them or you don't. Clearly not many people are too fond of the main character, Haruyuki Arita. He is drawn comically compared to the rest of the characters, but that is true to the source material, the light novel (although I think the anime made him shorter than the manga, which is unfortunate). But the story development itself, paired with the tech, are too fascinating to ignore. Due to the medium, the anime doesn't convey some of the background and subtle points for the character that are present in the light novel. I guess it falls back to most common conception how "the book is better than the movie."


The art is gorgeous. Backgrounds and the environments are highly detailed. The augmented reality UI, and duel avatars, the VR worlds, all are top notch. As expected from Sunrise. I'm still amazed how though-out the augmented reality UI is (the mail inbox notification, the logging out process, the awesome file transfer gesture, etc). 


It's been a while since I enjoy an anime this much. As a gadget geek, I'm truly fascinated with the tech. The unusual yet loveable main character, the cute avatars, the feel-warm story, gorgeous art, awesome music, it's hard for me not to be addicted to Accel World. If you have interest in Accel World, make sure to check out the manga, and even the light novel, as they will enrich and make the Accel World's world even more enjoyable.

Accel World is based on a light novel series of the same name, and takes place in a futuristic universe where virtual reality is commonplace. It tells the story of a boy, Haruyuki, and his discovery of a game called "Brain Burst." The game allows a player to assume a virtual identity and defeat others in-game in order to gain points and use them to 'accelerate' (slow down time) in real life.
AW’s storytelling definitely isn't perfect, but in spite of its faults, it manages to be incredibly enjoyable. The battle sequences are great, and the protagonists are easy to root for. I'd recommend it toanyone looking for a fun series that focuses more on action than logic.


| Story: 5 | Art: 10 | Sound: 9 | Character: 5 | Enjoyment: 9 |


Read on for the full review. Warning: contains mild spoilers.


= = = = = = = = = =


- The Universe -


The Good:

After watching the first few episodes, my interest was piqued: the premise--real-life underdog getting his chance to become a knight in shining armor via a virtual game--seemed decent, and the universe/setting was constructed well. Despite its generic school setting, AW maintained a futuristic theme, complete with holographic interfaces and thought-sharing cables. Virtual reality certainly isn't a novel concept, but AW pulled it off by combining it with modern school life themes. It's an interesting mix, and it sets AW apart from series like Sword Art Online or Btooom!, which delve entirely into the virtual aspect of their storylines. 


The Bad:

Like most shounen series, AW had a tendency to introduce new rules/abilities and reveal hidden information as the show progressed. For the most part, these "game changers" happened within the virtual side of the anime--the Accelerated World. Because of the world's RPG-like system, you'd think that the reveals would've made sense, since leveling up in an RPG amounts to gaining new abilities and information anyway. However, a lot the new abilities and information in AW felt more like cop-outs/deux ex machina that were just there to advance the plot, rather than enhance the universe.


- The Story -


The Good:

The first half of the anime was wonderful in terms of storytelling. Brain Burst and the Accelerated World were useful devices for facilitating character development, and it was nice to see the bonds between the characters evolve as they interacted with each other both in the Accelerated World and real life. Haruyuki's transformation from a rookie Burst Linker to the famed aviating Silver Crow was fun to follow, and it was nice to see him being trained by other characters.


The Bad:

Loose ends. A lot of them. I understand that the producers wanted to follow the plot of the light novel, but the shift in the story halfway through was a bit jarring. The goal established at the beginning of AW was to help Kuroyukihime defeat the other kings and reach Level 10. However, the second arc of the anime had KYH on a school trip, detached from most of the action. AW introduced a new antagonist and focused on the Haru/Taku/Chiyu trio’s efforts to defeat him. KYH was only brought back at the very end, to provide assistance in the final battle.


- The Characters -


The Good:

Character interactions were fun to watch, and AW had plenty of quirky figures. No character with an important role had a one-dimensional personality. KYH in particular was my favorite character in the series--beautiful, badass, and one hell of a Legion Master.


The Bad:

There was little character development, and a few characters were introduced without any backstory whatsoever. As well, Haruyuki didn't change as much throughout the series as I'd hoped. (Even one of the post-series OVAs spoofed his low self-confidence.) The series began with him as someone whose sense of self worth relied only on how powerful he was in the virtual world, and sadly, it seemed as though that trait didn't change, even towards the end of the show. During the second arc, he got his wings stolen by the main antagonist. After this happened, he fell into a depression and henceforth felt as though his wings were the only reason why KYH kept him around. KYH was clear about her adoration for him, but he never gained enough confidence to reciprocate her feelings. That was probably one of the series' biggest disappointments.

This series holds far too many similarities to Sword Art Online.
Characters have unique and completely overpowered ability: Check
Both series throw girls at the MC to the point where it should be a harem anime but isn't: Check
Both series have plot holes the size of the grand canyon: Check
Useless side characters that don't contribute much to the plot: Check
There were several episodes where I wanted to just drop the show because of how over-infatuated the main character was. Even for a romance anime, there was no real driving force between the main interest of the MC except her looks.
In the aspect of the game in theseries, it constantly changes. First it starts as one on one battles that can be initiated without the other person's consent. Then it adds the concept of tag-team matches. Then it indicates a free-for-all. Then it adds AI controlled monsters. The point is, it keeps adding new features and changing the games core to suite the plot. While I can understand revealing different features of the game to help drive the story, this takes it too far.

At the time of this review, I've only actually watched 19 episodes.  I intend to finish the anime, just cause I don't like leaving things half finished, but oh my god...it's getting painful.  Each episode is getting more and more boring than the last.
Pros? Great animation, cool armor design and what not.  On a fundamental level, it's cool.
Cons? Everything else.  Story is lame, characters are extremely two dimensional and lame, and without anything to back up the cool armor, it's just extremely boring.  I'd constantly put off watching the anime, cause although people said it was good, I just hadthis feeling that it it was nothing more than it's original premise, and my assumptions were, again, right.\n\n
As an anime, it feels like this guy just doodle some awesome armors and thought "Huh, I should animate this." without any consideration for what a good anime actually requires, that primarily being a story and characters of at least SOME note. With absolutely nothing backing it up beyond it's premise, it falls completely flat after the first few episodes.\n\n
After watching the 1st episode, I thought, okay, maybe this will go some where good.  After watching the 5th episode, I thought, Uhh...this is getting repetitive.\n
After the 10th episode I was getting really bored.\n
By the 15th episode I almost quit.  \n
Now, I've just finished the 19th episode and oh my god... I don't know if I can actually stomach the last 5 episodes.  Like, it's that bad.  The art can only carry an anime so far...like 3 episodes tops...  *sigh*  Another lame anime that gets recommended way to often.

So this is my very very first review after watching quite a bit of anime but... here it goes:
Story: 9/10
This story has a really good concept, considering it came from the same author as SAO.  The idea of having VR games and the like just sparks my geeky nerdy side.  I can't quite pinpoint it cause I am not much of a judge of storylines as of yet, so I apologize for my lack of depth in this part of the review, I promise to be more descriptive with the other parts.
Art: 8/10
Coming from someone who is used to watching anime from the90s, I seriously thought that the artwork for this anime was quite exquisite.  Although, the fight scenes could be a little bit more animated but hey who am I to judge. 


Sound: 9/10


What really drew me into this anime besides the story concept was the music.   Music that somewhat fits the scene is a plus and I say this anime hit it on point MOST of the time. I've watched some anime where the music was good but its timing was so off that it ruined the entire scene, so this was a pretty good improvement.  I also enjoyed the ending and openings of this anime which is another thing that drew me in.


Character: 3/10


Okay this is where I can get really critical.


Nothing irks me more than MCs who are either stupid, whiny, or any of the sort like that.  Now I don't mean for the MC to be a  perfect character like Kirito from SAO (too perfect is not a good thing either!) and I'm really tolerant when it comes to level of perversion and stupidity.  But Arita Haruyuki falls under the category of MCs that annoy me.


Biggest gripe: He's whiny. I mean its already bad enough that he's half the size of the other characters, but to make his personality just as bad as his outer appearance is just overkill.  Although there are times where he grows a pair and actually shines, but most of the time, he's either crying or whining over something that he had/lost like a little kid or realizing that shit just isn't going his way (being in Jr High in the anime timeline doesn't make it any better). I don't mean to sound mean but his school avatar of a pig pretty much fits him haha.


The other characters are pretty likeable in my opinion, although some of their actions still leave me asking.... why you do that?? *ahem* Chiyu *ahem*.


UPDATE 11/17/2013: After rewatching this series, I now understand what Chiyu did what she did... But man did it make me not like her for the longest time.  I also gave myself a mental whipping for missing important info such as this.  But my overall rating for this anime does not change.


Though my favorite has gotta be Kuroyukihime: dark past, and trying to repent for what she did is a good basis for an MC.... butttt she isn't the MC so oh well.


Enjoyment: 3/10


Even though it had an awesome storyline, maybe storytelling could've been better, the art and the sound is good enough to keep me going but the character mainly Arita is what ruined the anime for me.  His constant crying and hating on himself just made me really agitated that I was close to dropping the anime, but stuck to it cause I don't like leaving any anime unfinished.


Overall: 5/10


Gave it a 5/10 all because characters are what drives the show, if a half-assed character exists then that person either better develop into some bad ass by the middle-end of the series or you just eave the viewers going "wow eff this MC man".


Anyway, I have not read the light novels so I don't know how accurate the anime was to the original source but this was my two cents.

Ok, first time anime review writer here!
I won't go into detail about what all goes down for this anime, you can get wikipedia to do your dirty work for that.  Just to give you a personal opinion from a slightly biased p.o.v., I'd love to say that it is the first anime that has gotten me that addicted feeling in a while.  I've started and stopped countless anime's before this, but this one (once you let your self watch past the first episode) takes you for a ride in which every episode ends with a cliff hanger.  Sure the main character ischubby, but he is probably the only character who doesn't look like a model in the show.  Sure the artwork lacks the most detailed and colorful pictures you have ever witnessed in anime, but its not like they are down right crappy!  They are above average in my opinion as is the music.  It doesn't have that iconic song that you can put with your favorite anime but the music plays toward your emotions, escpecially the later couple of episodes when the main character/s reveal more of the plot to you.


The thing that makes this anime one of my favorites to date is that it has that predictable feeling yet you can't really guess how exactly the plot is going to play out, and it is a feel good anime unlike alot of others.  Besides that, the anime isn't very long (24 episodes) and if you start now, you'll only get through 5 episodes which is about 2 and a half hours of your time.


Just thought I'd point out that you shouldn't judge an anime by its cover, because this one could possibly (and I know this is kind of a stretch) get good enough to where you'll relate it to the like of Death Note or Lelouch.  I'm not saying it will be, and I can see how the main character can put you off, but just give it a chance and hopefully you'll NOT prove me wrong:)

This anime was fine. It wasn't terrible but it wasn't good either

Yes, thats how I percieved the anime, but its probably just me hating on the main character, but seriously he whines about how much of a loser he is like every flippin episode!! The idea of accel world wasn't bad though. So basically Accel World is a cyber world where characters transform to a metal suited avatar based on their mental scars. The avatarshave 6 different colors and each have different meanings (if you want to know more watch the anime! Lol) oh and the funny thing is chubby the main character (haruyuki) happens to be the only avatar that has a certain ability and certain color that has showed up in the history of Accel World. Well I guess that was his advantage of being the biggest loser. Ofcourse there are some fighting involved in order to get points that can be used as an advantage in the real life, but the downfall as usual is if you lose all your points your memory will be erased about the game.
